revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = Care Quality Commission | former name = | image = Care Quality Commission logo.svg | size = | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = CQC | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and age|2009|04}} | extinction = | type = [[Non-departmental public body]] | status = Operational | purpose = | headquarters = 151 [[Buckingham Palace Road]]
London, {{postcode|SW|1}} | location = | coords = {{coord|51.523042|-0.090166}} | region_served = England | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = Chief Executive | leader_name = Ian Trenholmhttps://www.cqc.org.uk/news/stories/cqc-board-appoints-ian-trenholm-new-chief-executive | leader_title2 = Chief Inspector of Hospitals | leader_name2 = Professor Ted Baker | leader_title3 = Chief Inspector of Adult Social Care | leader_name3 = [[Andrea Sutcliffe]] | key_people = Chief Inspector of Primary Care: [[Steve Field (medical doctor)|Prof Steve Field]] | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = £166m gross expenditure (2012/13){{cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/our-annual-report-2012/13 |title=Our annual report for 2012/13 |publisher=Care Quality Commission |date=11 July 2013 |accessdate=20 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714001132/http://www.cqc.org.uk/our-annual-report-2012/13 |archivedate=14 July 2013 |df=dmy }} | num_staff = 2,147 whole time equivalents (2012/13) | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.cqc.org.uk/ www.cqc.org.uk] | remarks = }} The '''Care Quality Commission''' ('''CQC''') is an executive [[non-departmental public body]] of the [[Department of Health and Social Care (United Kingdom)|Department of Health and Social Care]] of the [[United Kingdom]]. It was established in 2009 to regulate and inspect health and social care services in England. It was formed from three predecessor organisations: * the [[Healthcare Commission]] * the [[Commission for Social Care Inspection]] * the [[Mental Health Act Commission]] The CQC's stated role is to make sure that hospitals, care homes, dental and general practices and other care services in England provide people with safe, effective and high-quality care, and to encourage them to improve. It carries out this role through checks it carries out during the registration process all new care services must complete, inspections and monitoring of a range of data sources that can indicate problems with services. Part of the commission's remit is protecting the interests of people whose rights have been restricted under the [[Mental Health Act 1983|Mental Health Act]]. ==History== Until 31 March 2009, regulation of health and adult social care in England was carried out by the [[Healthcare Commission]] and the [[Commission for Social Care Inspection]]. The [[Mental Health Act Commission]] had monitoring functions with regard to the operation of the [[Mental Health Act 1983]]. The commission was established as a single, integrated regulator for England's health and adult social care services by the [[Health and Social Care Act 2008]]{{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2008/ukpga_20080014_en_1 |title=Office of Public Sector Information – Health and Social Care Act 2008 |publisher=Opsi.gov.uk |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2013-06-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2008/pdf/ukpga_20080014_en.pdf |title=Office of Public Sector Information – Health and Social Care Act 2008 (pdf) |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-06-24}}{{cite pressrelease | url = http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Legislation/Actsandbills/HealthandSocialCareBill/DH_080438 | publisher = [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] | date = 2007-11-16 | accessdate = 2008-09-16 | title = Care Quality Commission}} to replace these three bodies. The Commission was created in shadow form on 1 October 2008 and began operating on 1 April 2009. ==Organisation== {{inc-up|date=June 2018}} ===Board=== * Chair: [[Peter Wyman]], formerly chair of [[Yeovil District Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/peter-wyman-cbe-our-new-chair|title=Peter Wyman CBE – our new Chair|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2016}} *Dr Malte Gerhold, Interim Executive Director of Strategy and Intelligence{{cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dr-paul-bate |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509184418/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dr-paul-bate |archivedate=9 May 2016 |df=dmy }} *[[Eileen Milner]], Executive Director of Customer and Corporate Services{{Cite web |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/eileen-milner |title=Archived copy |access-date=19 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531135415/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/eileen-milner |archive-date=31 May 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} *Kirsty Shaw, Chief Operating Officerhttps://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/kirsty-shaw ====Chief inspectors==== The Commission has three chief inspectors who are also board members: * Professor Ted Baker: chief inspector of hospitalshttps://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/professor-ted-baker * [[Andrea Sutcliffe]]: chief inspector for social care{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/Andrea-Sutcliffe|title=Andrea Sutcliffe CBE {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} * Dr [[Steve Field (medical doctor)|Steve Field]]: chief inspector of general practice{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/professor-steve-field-cbe|title=Professor Steve Field, Chief Inspector of General Practice {{!}} www.cqc.org.uk|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}{{cite news|title=Steve Field appointed as chief inspector of general practice|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/primary-care/steve-field-appointed-as-chief-inspector-of-general-practice/5062619.article#.VE4fkyvraKI|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=28 August 2013}} ====Non-executive==== *[[Louis Appleby]], National Clinical Director for offender health, formerly the National Director for mental health. Appointed 3 June 2013.{{cite web|title=Manchester expert appointed to Care Quality Commission |date=12 June 2013 |work=[[The University of Manchester]] |url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/aboutus/news/display/?id=10212 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/professor-louis-appleby|title=Louis Appleby, Board member {{!}} www.cqc.org.uk|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} *[[Paul Corrigan (civil servant)|Paul Corrigan]], former health policy advisor to [[Tony Blair]] and former [[Special advisers (UK government)|special advisor]] to [[Alan Milburn]] and [[John Reid, Baron Reid of Cardowan|John Reid]]. Appointed 3 June 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/paul-corrigan|title=Paul Corrigan, Board member {{!}} www.cqc.org.uk|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} *[[Jennifer Dixon]], chief executive of the [[Nuffield Trust]] and past board member of the [[Healthcare Commission]]. Appointed 3 June 2013.{{cite web|title=Care Quality Commission appoints new board members |date=3 June 2013 |work=Care Quality Commission |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/media/care-quality-commission-appoints-new-board-members |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20131118125406/http://www.cqc.org.uk/media/care-quality-commission-appoints-new-board-members |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dr-jennifer-dixon |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531141453/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dr-jennifer-dixon |archivedate=31 May 2016 |df= }} *[[Robert Francis (barrister)|Robert Francis QC]] Appointed 4 June 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/cqc-welcomes-new-board-members|title=CQC welcomes new Board members {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/sir-robert-francis-qc|title=Sir Robert Francis QC {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} *[[Michael Mire]], a senior partner at [[McKinsey & Company]]. Appointed 3 June 2013.{{Cite web |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/michael-mire |title=Archived copy |access-date=19 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531135310/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/michael-mire |archive-date=31 May 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} *[[Jane Mordue]], interim chair of [[Healthwatch England]], former deputy chair of [[Citizens Advice]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/department-health-seeks-recruit-new-chair-healthwatch-england|title=Department of Health seeks to recruit new Chair of Healthwatch England {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/jane-mordue|title=Jane Mordue {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} *[[Paul Rew]] Appointed 4 June 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/paul-rew|title=Paul Rew {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} *Mark Saxton. Appointed 1 March 2018.https://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/mark-saxton *Liz Sayce. Appointed January 2018.https://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/liz-sayce-obe *Jora Gillhttps://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/jora-gill *Sir John Oldham. Appointed January 2018.https://www.cqc.org.uk/about-us/meet-our-team/sir-john-oldham ===Previous board members=== Previous board members have included: * Chief executive: [[Cynthia Bower]] 2009–2012{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/exclusive-interview-ive-been-hung-out-to-dry-with-no-chance-to-air-my-side-of-the-story-cynthia-8671955.html|title=Exclusive interview – 'I've been hung out to dry, with no chance to|date=2013-06-24|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} * Chief executive: [[David Behan]] 2012-2018https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/jul/11/cqc-david-behan-care-safer-quality-better * Chair: [[David Prior, Baron Prior of Brampton|David Prior]] 2013–2015,{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/people/david-prior|title=Lord Prior of Brampton – GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} [[Jo Williams]] 2010–2012,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-19520014|title=Care regulator chair to resign|date=2012-09-07|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} [[Barbara Young, Baroness Young of Old Scone]] 2008–2009.https://uk.linkedin.com/in/barbara-young-5377b020{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Sir [[Michael Adrian Richards|Mike Richards]]: chief inspector of hospitals 2013-2017{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/professor-sir-mike-richards|title=Professor Ted Baker {{!}} Care Quality Commission|website=www.cqc.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}https://www.cqc.org.uk/news/stories/professor-sir-mike-richards-retire ==Operations== In August 2013 the CQC stated that it was finding it difficult to meet their inspection target of GP practices and had therefore drafted in 'bank' inspectors and authorised staff overtime to deal with the backlog.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/practice-topics/regulation/fifth-of-gp-practices-inspected-by-the-cqc-found-to-be-non-compliant/20004027.article|title=Fifth of GP practices inspected by the CQC found to be 'non-compliant'|work=Pulse Today|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} In October 2014 Field announced that the Commission was going to begin inspecting health systems across whole geographical areas from 2015, including social care and [[NHS 111]].{{cite news|title=CQC to inspect whole health systems|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/topics/nhs-regulation-and-inspection/cqc-to-inspect-whole-health-systems/5075504.article#.VE4gUCvraKI|accessdate=27 October 2014|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=6 October 2014}} There are suggestions that it could inspect [[clinical commissioning group]]s.{{cite news|title=CQC to assess whole health systems|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/primary-care/cqc-to-assess-whole-health-systems/5089538.article#.VhIzIkpfZ1A|accessdate=5 October 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=11 August 2015}} Behan admitted in March 2015 that the Commission would not be able to inspect all acute trusts before the end of 2015 as it had intended.{{cite news|title=CQC will miss own inspection deadlines, regulator admits|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/cqc-will-miss-own-inspection-deadlines-regulator-admits/5083618.article#.VRbW9vmsVyU|accessdate=28 March 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=25 March 2015}} In February 2015 it reported that it was missing its targets for following up on the safeguarding information it received that might indicate that patients are at risk.{{cite news|title=CQC falls short in responding to safeguarding alerts|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/cqc-falls-short-in-responding-to-safeguarding-alerts/5082754.article#.VRbZJfmsVyU|accessdate=28 March 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=26 February 2015}} He also said the CQC would update its oversight in line with the growth of new provider models and would begin looking at care quality along pathways to a greater degree and, for the first time, across localities.{{cite news|title=CQC unveils new approach to regulating forward view care models|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/exclusive-cqc-unveils-new-approach-to-regulating-forward-view-care-models/5083137.article#.VSGdsPnF9yU|accessdate=5 April 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=10 March 2015}} The organisation failed to meet its inspection targets during the second quarter of 2015–16. 70% of adult social care inspections had been undertaken and 61% of primary medical services. An exception to this was inspections of hospital acute services where targets were slightly exceeded, an additional 2 inspections having been made in this sector.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/Health-Care-News/slumping-productivity-hits-cqc-inspection-regime|title=Slumping productivity hits CQC inspection regime|website=www.nationalhealthexecutive.com|access-date=2018-03-28}} In December 2015 the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) was critical of the regulator, and said that it was "behind where it should be, six years after it was established”. Meg Hillier MP, the chair of the PAC, noted that reports prepared by the CQC contained many errors; one foundation trust said that their staff had found more than 200 errors in a draft CQC report. Hillier said "The fact these errors were picked up offers some reassurance, but this is clearly unacceptable from a public body in which taxpayers are placing their trust.”{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/Health-Care-News/cqc-not-an-effective-regulator-and-unprepared-for-2016-duties--pac|title=CQC ‘not an effective regulator’ and unprepared for 2016 duties – PAC|website=www.nationalhealthexecutive.com|access-date=2018-03-28}} In July 2016 the commission issued an apology after admitting that up to 500 Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) certificates submitted by applicants to become registered managers and providers had been lost during a planned office refurbishment; a locked filing cabinet had been incorrectly marked up to be taken away and destroyed.{{cite news |url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/regulation/gps-details-included-in-500-confidential-records-lost-by-cqc/20032423.fullarticle |title=GPs' details included in 500 confidential records lost by CQC |first=Alex |last=Matthews-King |work=Pulse |date=29 July 2016 |accessdate=12 September 2016}} In the period of August 2016 to January 2017 the CQC sent questionnaires to inpatients of NHS hospitals who had been service users in the month of July 2016. 77,850 surveys were sent out.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wirralglobe.co.uk/news/15346896.Patients_rate_Clatterbridge_Cancer_Centre_one_of__best__hospitals_in_the_country/|title=Patients rate Clatterbridge Cancer Centre one of 'best' hospitals in the country|website=Wirral Globe|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} In October 2016 a briefing paper issued by the organisation stated that no directorate was meeting objectives for producing reports on time. Of services which had been inspected over half had not improved their rating when re-inspected, with 45% staying at the same rating and 10% having a lower rating.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/Health-Care-News/cqc-to-bring-in-external-consultants-in-january-as-all-inspections-still-behind-target|title=CQC to bring in external consultants as inspections still behind target|website=www.nationalhealthexecutive.com|access-date=2018-03-28}} Following the cyber attacks on NHS systems in May 2017 it was announced that the CQC will be asking probing questions to assess data security as part of its inspection process.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2c4d7474-398a-11e7-821a-6027b8a20f23|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}} After the Grenfell Tower fire in June 2017 letters were sent to around 17,000 care homes, hospitals and hospices requesting that they review fire safety processes, paying particular attention to the safety of service users who were more vulnerable due to mobility issues or learning disabilities.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/grenfell-tower-fire-latest-17000-care-homes-hospitals-hospices-safety-checks-a7810486.html|title=17,000 hospitals and care homes ordered to carry out fire safety reviews|date=2017-06-27|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} In March 2018 the Public Accounts Committee reported that although the regulator had "improved significantly" there was "no room for complacency" in the organisation which had “persistent weaknesses and looming challenges”. Whilst there had been improvements in the timeliness of hospital inspection reports since 2015, only 25% of reports on hospitals where less than 3 services were inspected were published within the target of 50 days. It was intended that 90% of reports should meet the target. The PAC also noted that GPs had felt burdened by the CQC's regulation practices. In response David Behan stated that he accepted the committee's recommendations and did not underestimate the task at hand.{{cite news |title=PAC: Health regulator has ‘persistent weaknesses’ |url=https://www.publicfinance.co.uk/news/2018/03/pac-health-regulator-has-persistent-weaknesses |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Public Finance}} In July 2018 the CQC stated that 96 safeguarding concerns had not been passed on to local authorities over the last 12 months. Andrea Sutcliffe, acting chief executive of the CQC said that an urgent review was carried out when the issue was discovered and it was found that "none of these referrals contained information about immediate risk of severe harm to people". Sutcliffe apologised for the error and said an independent investigation "will assist us in ensuring we improve our systems to avoid something like this happening again".{{cite news |title=CQC launches investigation after referrals blunder |url=https://www.digitalhealth.net/2018/07/cqc-launches-investigation-after-referrals-blunder/ |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Digital Health |date=27 July 2018}} In October 2018 CQC's Chief Executive Ian Trenholm stated that he wanted to make the information held by the organisation more widely available to the public and that he also intended to make CQC an easier organisation to do business with and a better place to work. A chief digital officer was to be appointed as part of this process.{{cite news |author1=Shaun Lintern |title=CQC data to be open to public, promises new chief |url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/policy-and-regulation/cqc-data-to-be-open-to-public-promises-new-chief/7023698.article |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Health Service Journal |date=31 October 2018}} ==Hospital inspections== ===Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust=== In November 2009 [[Barbara Young, Baroness Young of Old Scone|Barbara Young]], then the CQC chair, resigned from the commission when a report detailing poor standards at [[Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] was leaked to the media. The report found that "hundreds of people had died needlessly due to appalling standards of care."{{Cite news |title=Baroness Young, health watchdog chief, to stand down |date=4 December 2009 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/6730920/Baroness-Young-health-watchdog-chief-to-stand-down.html |accessdate=20 June 2013}} One month earlier the commission had rated the quality of care at the hospital as "good."{{Cite news|title=Taskforce sent in to raise standards at Essex NHS trust |date=26 November 2009 |work=[[BBC News]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/8381118.stm |accessdate=20 June 2013}}{{Cite news|title=NHS watchdog chief Barbara Young quits after Essex hospital furore |first=Denis |last=Campbell |date=4 December 2009 |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2009/dec/04/cqc-barbara-young-quits-hospitals-essex|accessdate=20 June 2013}} ===Grant Thornton report=== {{main|Furness General Hospital scandal}} In August 2012 chief executive [[David Behan]] commissioned a report by management consultants [[Grant Thornton]].{{Cite news|title=NHS Watchdog accused of hospital 'cover-up' still not fit for purpose, chairman admits |first=Peter |last=Dominiczak |date=19 June 2013 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/10129223/Watchdog-accused-of-hospital-cover-up-still-not-fit-for-purpose-chairman-admits.html |accessdate=19 June 2013}} The report examined the CQC's response to complaints about baby and maternal deaths and injuries at [[Furness General Hospital]] in [[Barrow-in-Furness|Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria]] and was instigated by a complaint from a member of the public and "an allegation of a "cover-up" submitted by a [[whistleblower]] at CQC."{{cite web|title=The Care Quality Commission re: Project Ambrose |work=Care Quality Commission |date=14 June 2013 |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/sites/default/files/media/documents/grant_thornton_uk_llp_morecambe_bay.pdf |accessdate=19 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130717143550/http://www.cqc.org.uk/sites/default/files/media/documents/grant_thornton_uk_llp_morecambe_bay.pdf |archivedate=17 July 2013 |df=dmy }}{{Cite news|date=19 June 2013 |title=Healthcare regulator CQC 'may have covered up failings' |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-22949211 |accessdate=19 June 2013}} It was published on 19 June 2013.{{Cite news|title=NHS watchdog covered-up scandal at hospital where eight babies died of neglect |first=Charlie |last=Cooper |work=[[The Independent]] |location=London |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/nhs-watchdog-coveredup-scandal-at-hospital-where-eight-babies-died-of-neglect-8664224.html |accessdate=19 June 2013 |date=19 June 2013}} Among the findings, the CQC was "accused of quashing an internal review that uncovered weaknesses in its processes" and had allegedly "deleted the review of their failure to act on concerns about University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Trust." One CQC employee claimed that he was instructed by a senior manager "to destroy his review because it would expose the regulator to public criticism." The report concluded: "We think that the information contained in the [deleted] report was sufficiently important that the deliberate failure to provide it could properly be characterised as a '[[cover-up]]'."{{Cite news|title=Cover-up over hospital scandal |first=Laura |last=Donnelly |date=18 Jun 2013 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/healthnews/10128886/Cover-up-over-hospital-scandal.html |accessdate=19 June 2013}} David Prior, who joined the commission as chairman in January 2013, responded that the organisation's previous management had been "totally dysfunctional" and admitted that the organisation was "not fit for purpose."{{Cite news|title=NHS regulator exposed as 'not fit for purpose' by maternity deaths |first=Haroon |last=Siddique |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=19 June 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/19/nhs-regulator-cqc-cover-up-morecambe-bay |accessdate=19 June 2013}} On 20 June 2013, Behan and Prior agreed to release the names of previously redacted senior managers within the Grant Thornton report, who it is alleged had suppressed the internal CQC report. The people named were former CQC Chief Executive Cynthia Bower, deputy CEO Jill Finney and media manager Anna Jefferson. All were reportedly present at a meeting where deletion of a critical report was allegedly discussed. Bower and Jefferson immediately denied being involved in a cover-up.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-22992625|title=NHS 'cover-up' names revealed by CQC|first=Nick|last=Triggle|work=[[BBC News]]|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=20 June 2013}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper reported on 19 June 2013 that [[Tim Farron]] MP had written to the [[Metropolitan Police]] asking them to investigate the alleged cover-up.{{cite news|author=Randeep Ramesh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jun/19/met-nhs-regulator-morecambe-farron |title=Met asked to investigate NHS regulator after Morecambe Bay trust report|publisher=Guardian |date=2013-06-19 |accessdate=2013-06-24 |location=London}} Following an investigation, CQC found that Jefferson had not been party to any alleged 'delete' instruction. Jefferson was cleared of any wrong-doing and CQC apologised for the distress caused by the allegation.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-24390570|title=CQC official Anna Jefferson cleared over 'cover-up'|work=BBC News|accessdate=22 March 2016}} Finney subsequently started litigation seeking at least £1.3 million libel damages from the CQC on the basis that the CQC’s current chair David Prior and chief executive David Behan abused their power and acted maliciously in publishing allegations that she ordered a “cover-up” of its failings. The Grant Thornton report said it was “more likely than not” that Ms Finney had ordered the deletion of an internal report by Louise Dineley, the CQC’s head of regulatory risk. The CQC started litigation against Grant Thornton claiming a contribution towards any “damages, interests and/or costs” incurred in the case.{{cite web|title=CQC drags Grant Thornton into libel court case|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/workforce/cqc-drags-grant-thornton-into-libel-court-case/5073296.article#.U_4_o_ldUk4|publisher=Health Service Journal|accessdate=27 August 2014|date=28 July 2014}} ==Social care== Residential establishments, unlike hospitals, can easily be closed, or sold, and reopened with a new identity. [[Private Eye]] reported in November 2015 that most of the 34 homes closed under [[Cynthia Bower]] after failing their inspection later reopened with a new name or under new ownership, but with similar problems. [[Compassion in Care]] told the magazine that if a home changed name or ownership it was then listed by the CQC as "new services" and "uninspected" by the CQC, and there was no link to reports on the same establishment under different ownership, even if the new owners were linked to the previous owners, and there was no follow up inspection if problems had been identified. They had found 152 homes reregistered as new, when they had only changed owner or name. The Commission had identified safety concerns in more than 40% of the homes it had inspected, and 10% were rated as inadequate.{{cite news|title=Sleeping Watchdog|issue=1405|publisher=Private Eye|date=13 November 2015|page=37}} In April 2016 it was reported that 44% of care homes in the South East inspected over an 18 month period were rated as inadequate or requiring improvement. Only 0.9% of the 1200 homes inspected were rated as outstanding.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-36149910|title=Care home resident 'month without bath'|date=2016-04-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} In September 2016 the CQC said that 40% of nursing homes in the country were rated as "requiring improvement" or "inadequate".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37496349|title=Nursing homes 'closing each week'|last=Atkinson|first=Carolyn|date=2016-09-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} It is a legal requirement for homes to clearly display their CQC ratings on their websites but a July 2017 survey carried out by Which? found that 27% of care homes surveyed either completely failed to display them or placed them where they were very difficult to find.{{Cite news|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/lifestyle/money/father-care-home-died-care-home-refused-refund-unspent-fees/|title=When my father died, his care home refused to refund any unspent fees – iNews|date=2017-07-19|work=iNews|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} As of September 2018 the CQC rated almost 3,000 out of 14,975 care homes in England as inadequate or needing improvement.https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-45194202 The care home Horncastle House was closed by CQC in September 2018 as an urgent enforcement action to protect residents. The owner Sussex Healthcare stated that they were disappointed by the CQC's decision to close the service and did not accept the allegations which had led to the closure.http://www.carehomeprofessional.com/residents-told-leave-immediately-sussex-care-home-shut/ ===Winterbourne View=== {{main|Winterbourne View hospital abuse}} Winterbourne View was a private hospital at [[Hambrook]], [[South Gloucestershire]], owned and operated by Castlebeck. It was exposed in a ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' investigation into [[physical abuse|physical]] and [[psychological abuse]] suffered by people with [[learning disabilities]] and [[challenging behaviour]], first broadcast in 2011.{{cite news|date=1 June 2011 |title=Four arrests after patient abuse caught on film |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13548222 |accessdate=20 June 2013}} One senior nurse had reported his concerns directly to CQC, but his complaint was not taken up.{{cite news |date=18 July 2011 |title=Winterbourne View 'failed to protect people' |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-14181646 |accessdate=20 June 2013}} The public funded hospital was shut down as a result of the abuse that took place.{{cite news|title=Winterbourne View 'abuse' hospital closes on Friday |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-13891855 |date=24 June 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2013}} [[Cynthia Bower]], then the chief executive of the commission, resigned ahead of a critical government report in which Winterbourne View was cited.{{cite news|title=NHS watchdog chief Cynthia Bower resigns |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/feb/23/nhs-watchdog-cynthia-bower-resigns |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |first=Denis |last=Campbell|date=23 February 2013 |accessdate=20 June 2013}} ===Ash Court=== Ash Court is a residential [[nursing home]] for the elderly in London, operated by [[Forest Healthcare]].{{Cite news|title=Abuse secretly filmed in 'excellent' London care home |date=23 April 2012 |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17810136 |accessdate=21 June 2013}} In April 2012 [[hidden camera]] footage was broadcast in a BBC ''Panorama'' exposé which showed an elderly woman being physically assaulted at Ash Court by a male carer and mistreated by four others. The standard of care at the nursing home had been rated "excellent."{{Cite news|date=23 April 2012 |title=Regulator criticised after woman assaulted in care home |work=[[BBC News]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-17777113 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}{{Cite news|title=Stafford hospital investigator berates CQC regulator |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/may/01/stafford-hospital-investigator-berates-cqc-regulator |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |first=John |last=Carvel |date=1 May 2012 |accessdate=21 June 2013}} The victim was an 81-year-old woman suffering [[Alzheimer's disease]] and severe [[arthritis]]. Although the commission's primary function is to enforce national standards including safeguarding the vulnerable and "enabling them to live free from harm, abuse and neglect" the CQC responded by stating that they "should not be criticised for failing to protect people from harm" and could not be expected to spot abuse "which often takes place behind closed doors."{{cite web|title=The National Standards: Safeguarding people |work=Care Quality Commission |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/public/what-are-standards/safeguarding-people |accessdate=21 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623232508/http://www.cqc.org.uk/public/what-are-standards/safeguarding-people |archivedate=23 June 2013 |df=dmy }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.camdennewjournal.com/news/2012/apr/ash-court-abuse-leads-calls-public-inquiry-care-watchdog|title=Ash Court abuse leads to calls for public inquiry into care watchdog {{!}} Camden New Journal|last=|first=|date=2016-03-04|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030117/http://www.camdennewjournal.com/news/2012/apr/ash-court-abuse-leads-calls-public-inquiry-care-watchdog|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-03}} ==Primary care== In January 2015 the Commission for the first time took action in respect of primary care. Three GP practices were put into special measures after unsatisfactory inspection results: Priory Avenue Surgery in [[Reading, Berkshire]]; Dr Michael Florin’s surgery in [[Sale, Greater Manchester]]; and Dr Srinivas Dharmana’s family and general practice in [[Walton, Liverpool|Walton]], Liverpool.{{cite news|title=Three GP surgeries put into special measures over patient safety concerns|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/jan/22/three-gp-surgeries-special-measures-patient-safety-concerns?CMP=twt_gu|accessdate=22 January 2015|publisher=The Guardian|date=22 January 2015}} Priory Avenue Surgery was taken out of the special measures category later in 2015; it was rated "good" for being caring and "requires improvement" for being safe, effective, responsive and well led.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-berkshire-34341290|title=GP surgery out of special measures|date=2015-09-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}} The CQC considered cancelling the registration of Dharmana’s Family and General Practice, which would have forced it to close. This did not come about as Dr Dharmana voluntarily closed the service in December 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/walton-gp-surgery-shut-after-10220365|title=Liverpool GP surgery to shut due to untrained staff and lack of vital equipment|last=Taylor|first=Joshua|date=2015-10-08|work=liverpoolecho|access-date=2018-03-28}} In October 2016 the CQC's annual report stated that around 800,000 patients were registered with a GP practice assessed as inadequate on safety grounds by their inspectors.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/oct/13/social-care-cuts-take-english-service-to-tipping-point-regulator-warns|title=Social care cuts take English service to tipping point, regulator warns|last=Campbell|first=Denis|date=2016-10-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} By February 2017 the CQC had completed inspections of all GP practices which were registered before 1 October 2014. This amounted to more than 8,000 inspections.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/regulation/cqc-completes-its-first-round-of-gp-practice-inspections/20033893.article|title=CQC completes its first round of GP practice inspections|work=Pulse Today|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} In September 2017 the report State of Care in General Practice, 2014–2017 was published. It stated that 90% of practices were rated 'good' or 'outstanding'. The report also said that a causal relationship between levels of NHS funding and ratings had not been found, acknowledging that this is "a complex area that may benefit from further work."{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/regulation/practice-ratings-not-linked-to-lack-of-funding-claims-cqc/20035322.article|title=Practice ratings 'not linked' to lack of funding, claims CQC|work=Pulse Today|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} In January 2018 it was announced that the CQC would begin to inspect independent doctors providing online services.https://www.gov.uk/government/news/independent-doctors-to-be-rated-by-the-care-quality-commission The CQC's State of Care report for 2017/18 found that 91% of GP practices were rated as Good and 5% Outstanding.https://www.gponline.com/cqc-rates-96-practices-good-outstanding-despite-rising-pressure/article/1495774 ==Staffing== In a report to the audit committee revealed by the [[Health Service Journal]] in July 2014 it was reported that the Commission had employed 134 applicants in 2012 who “failed some or all of its recruitment activities”. Of that group 121 were still in post. The report said: “This in essence implies that our regulatory judgments may be impaired as we have not always appointed staff with the core competencies required to do the job properly, and they may not have received appropriate training to bring them up to the standard required.”{{cite news|title=CQC hired inspectors who failed recruitment criteria in 'flawed' process|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/exclusive-cqc-hired-inspectors-who-failed-recruitment-criteria-in-flawed-process/5072746.article#.U_5MXvldUk4|accessdate=27 August 2014|work=Health Service Journal|date=9 July 2014}} In the same month the chief executive David Behan said that recruiting extra inspectors was taking longer than expected due to the "high standards" set for new recruits. As a result some teams were operating at 50% capacity. In response to this situation the number of inspections scheduled for the second half of 2014 was scaled back.[http://www.hsj.co.uk/home/cqc-to-slow-inspections-amid-staff-pressures/5073416.fullarticle] A report of the CQC board in December 2014 showed the organisation had 852 full-time equivalent inspectors in post but a target of 1,411 by December 2015 – the number needed to “discharge the commitments that we’ve made in our business plan”.{{cite news|title=CQC needs to increase inspection workforce by 66pc in one year|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/cqc-needs-to-increase-inspection-workforce-by-66pc-in-one-year/5077798.article#.VM-JfZ2sVyU|accessdate=2 February 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=18 December 2014}} ==Funding== The budget for 2015/6 was £249 million, but is to be reduced to £236 million for 2016/7.{{cite news|title=CQC's budget cut further|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/topics/policy-and-regulation/cqcs-budget-cut-further/7004170.article|accessdate=2 May 2016|publisher=Health Service JOurnal|date=20 April 2016}} It is anticipated that by 2019/20 the budget will be £217 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.cqc.org.uk/sites/default/files/20160523_strategy_16-21_strategy_final_web_01.pdf |title=Strategy paper|website=cqc.org.uk}} It had a budget of £1.1 million for “travel and subsistence” for hospital inspections in 2014–15, but actually spent £4.4 million.{{cite news|title=Hospital inspections exceeded hotel and travel budget by four times|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/topics/policy-and-regulation/exclusive-hospital-inspections-exceeded-hotel-and-travel-budget-by-four-times/7000189.article|accessdate=19 December 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=16 November 2015}} In response to a Freedom of information request in November 2015 it was stated that CQC have a database support contract with Computacenter which costs approximately £700,000 per annum; the contract expires in September 2016 with the option of a 1 year extension.{{Cite web|url=https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/299956/response/736240/attach/html/3/20151120%20FOIA%20Response%20CQC%20IAT%201516%200562.doc.html|title=20151120 FOIA Response CQC IAT 1516 0562.doc|website=www.whatdotheyknow.com|access-date=2018-03-28}} Substantial increases are expected in future years as it moves to a full cost recovery basis.{{cite news|title=Trust CQC fees could increase by 75 per cent next year|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/home/trust-cqc-fees-could-increase-by-75-per-cent-next-year/5091630.article|accessdate=12 December 2015|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=2 November 2015}} NHS Providers described the decision to increase fees as "regrettable".{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/Health-Care-News/government-decision-to-push-ahead-with-cqc-fee-rise-regrettable-nhs-providers|title=DH decision to allow CQC fee rise ‘regrettable’ – NHS Providers|website=www.nationalhealthexecutive.com|access-date=2018-03-28}} For 2016/7 fees will increase by 75% as its government funding is reduced by 25%. The increase in fee levels has been criticised by the Registered Nursing Home association (RNHA), Care England and the Voluntary Organisations Disability Group (VODG).{{Cite web|url=http://www.careinfo.org/so-much-for-consultation-say-providers-in-the-wake-of-cqc-fee-increase/|title=‘So much for consultation’ say providers in the wake of CQC fee increase {{!}} Careinfo.org|website=www.careinfo.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-28}} Fees relate to the size and type of organisation and have been increased on a yearly basis: {| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" | CQC Fees |- ! scope="col" | Year !! scope="col" | GP Practice on one site with 5,000-10000 patients !! scope="col" | NHS Trust, with turnover between £125 million and £225 million !! scope="col" | Care Home 26–30 residents |- ! scope="row" | 2015/6 | £725{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/your-practice/regulation/how-much-more-am-i-going-to-have-to-pay-the-cqc/20030558.article|title=How much more am I going to have to pay the CQC?|work=Pulse Today|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} || £78,208{{Cite web|url=https://www.bma.org.uk/news/2016/january/gps-and-trusts-face-exorbitant-cqc-fees-hike|title=BMA – GPs and trusts face 'exorbitant' CQC fees hike|website=www.bma.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} || £761 |- ! scope="row" | 2016/7 | £2,574 || £136,864{{Cite web|url=https://www.bma.org.uk/news/2016/april/fees-make-mockery-of-cqc-consultation|title=BMA – Fees make 'mockery' of CQC consultation|website=www.bma.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}} || £4212{{Cite news|url=http://www.carehomeprofessional.com/cqc-to-hike-care-home-fees/|title=CQC to hike care home fees|date=2016-10-21|work=Care Home Professional|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-US}} |- ! scope="row" | 2017/8 | £4,526 || £202,239 || £4,375{{Cite news|url=http://www.careappointments.co.uk/practice-reports/item/41457-cqc-publish-regulatory-fees-for-care-providers-from-april-2017|title=CQC publish regulatory fees for care providers from April 2017|last=Team|first=The Editorial|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-gb}} |} ==Related issues== * [[Criticism of the National Health Service]] ==See also== * [[Eileen Chubb]] * [[Eileen Sills]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.cqc.org.uk Official website] {{Department of Health (United Kingdom)}} [[Category:Government agencies established in 2009]] [[Category:Health in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Local government in England]] [[Category:Medical regulation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:National Health Service (England)]] [[Category:Non-departmental public bodies of the United Kingdom government]] [[Category:Organisations based in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:2009 establishments in England]] [[Category:Social care in England]]

{{orphan|date=June 2010}} '''Cleo Spurlock Wallace''' (July 29, 1914 - August 26, 1985) was an American [[speech therapy|speech therapist]] born in [[Garo, Colorado]].
In 1933, Spurlock was one of the first six recipients of four-year scholarships to the [[University of Denver]]; she graduated in 1937. That same year, she married investment broker Thomas Wallace.
She subsequently earned a [[Rockefeller Foundation]] Teaching Fellowship to the University of Denver, where she received a master's degree in speech pathology in 1943.
Wallace then began teaching high school, where she received her first referral from a local physician. She worked with the child after school in her home; before long, she began treating other children with speech and language disorders. In 1948, to meet the needs of her growing clientele, she purchased two buildings with the help of businessman Henry Winter<ref name="Penrose Library">[http://library.du.edu/site/ Penrose Library] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601012123/http://library.du.edu/site/ |date=2010-06-01 }}</ref> and founded Wallace Village for Children, a nonprofit organization. When her husband died that same year, she turned all of her attention to her work. She paid one dollar for a five-year lease on a building at 4414 Logan Street, and moved in with five teachers and thirty students.
By 1954, the Wallace Village for Children was the beneficiary of community support, and with local assistance, the organization purchased {{convert|84|acre|m2}} at 100th Avenue and Wadsworth, the site of today’s Westminster Campus. At that time, residential services were added to the outpatient and day treatment programs. In 1974, Wallace retired, but remained actively involved until her death in 1985. In 1986, the organization’s name was changed to the Cleo Wallace Center and later to Devereux Cleo Wallace after its affiliation with the Devereux Foundation.
Wallace received numerous awards during her lifetime related to her work with children with disabilities. These awards included the [[Evans Award]] from the University of Denver Alumni Association, representing the highest honor awarded by the Alumni Association. She also received an appointment to the [[White House]] Conference on Services for Handicapped Children, and a presidential appointment to the National Advisory of Neurological Diseases and Stroke Council.<ref name="Penrose Library"/>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cleowallace.org Cleo Wallace Center] (now affiliated with the [[Devereux Foundation]] * [http://digital.library.du.edu/findingaids/view?docId=ead/m073.xml;query=;brand=default Guide to the Cleo Wallace Papers at the University of Denver] Retrieved 2104-10-01.
==References== *http://www.devereux.org/site/PageServer?pagename=co_about *https://web.archive.org/web/20100601012123/http://library.du.edu/site/ *http://www.devereux.org
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wallace, Cleo Spurlock}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:University of Denver alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:Speech and language pathologists]]

revision.text:
'''Concomitant drugs''' are two or more [[drug]]s used or given at or almost at the same time (one after the other, on the same day, etc.). The term has two contextual uses: as used in [[medicine]] or as used in [[drug abuse]].
== Concomitant drugs in medicine == This designation is used when medicinal drugs are given either at the same time or almost at the same time. This is often the case in medicine.
===First example=== Chemotherapy for cancer applies as an example. The standard of care (sometimes also called the "gold standard") for the adjuvant treatment of stage III colon cancer is the FOLFOX chemotherapy protocol (used in Europe, Japan, Canada, and Australia) and respectively the FLOX chemotherapy protocol (used in the USA). These 2 chemotherapy protocols are very similar in principle. Both consist of 3 medicinal drugs: a) Leucovorin (= folinic acid = calcium folinate), b) 5-Fluorouracil (= 5-FU), and c) Oxaliplatin. Since these 3 medicinal drugs are "concomitant" to each other, such a constellation is called "concomitant drugs".<ref>http://www.bccancer.bc.ca/HPI/ChemotherapyProtocols/default.htm</ref>
===Second example=== Contrast imaging in medicine is another example. These are imaging procedures in medicine that are performed after giving the patient an iodinated contrast medium (e.g. different types of contrast X-rays, CTs, MRIs). It is well known that such iodinated contrast media can lead to acute allergies in some patients. They may also lead to kidney damage. If the patient is receiving a "concomitant" medicinal drug (prescribed to the patient by another physician), and the radiologist performing the imaging procedure is unaware of this, potentially harmful side-effects can occur and increase the risk of contrast medium-induced nephropathy (i.e. increase the risk of damage to the kidneys). In general, radiologists carefully ask their patients about other medicinal drugs they are "concomitantly" taking before the imaging procedure. Often, they monitor the kidney function and the hydration status of their patients during the imaging procedure, especially whenever a concomitant drug (that is harmful to the kidney) is being used.<ref>Pannu N, Wiebe N, Tonelli M; Alberta Kidney Disease Network. Prophylaxis strategies for contrast-induced nephropathy. JAMA. 2006 Jun 21;295(23):2765-79. Review.</ref>
== Concomitant drugs in drug abuse == If a drug abuser ingests or misuses two or more drugs, either at the same time or almost at the same time, this is also called "concomitant drugs".
===Example=== Whether concomitant drug abuse leads to an increased number of deaths was scientifically analysed in Sheffield, UK.<ref name ="Sheffield" /> The researchers wanted to find out whether concomitant drug abuse (i.e. an opiate plus another drug of misuse) leads to an increased number of acute accidental opiate-related deaths. The authors showed that at least in the Sheffield area, intravenous (IV) administration of an opiate is the most consistent factor associated with drug abuse deaths. The co-administration of a concomitant drug of misuse appeared to be a feature rather than a risk factor per se in such deaths.<ref name ="Sheffield">Oliver P, Keen J. Concomitant drugs of misuse and drug using behaviours associated with fatal opiate-related poisonings in Sheffield, UK, 1997-2000. Addiction. 2003 Feb;98(2):191-7.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Pharmacy]]

'''Control banding''' is a qualitative or semi-quantitative [[risk assessment]] and [[risk management|management]] approach to promoting [[occupational health and safety]]. It is intended to minimize worker exposures to hazardous chemicals and other risk factors in the workplace and to help small businesses by providing an easy-to-understand, practical approach to controlling hazardous exposures at work.
The principle of control banding was first applied to dangerous chemicals, chemical mixtures, and fumes. The control banding process emphasizes the controls needed to prevent hazardous substances from causing harm to people at work. The greater the potential for harm, the greater the degree of control needed to manage the situation and make the risk “acceptable.” <ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/ctrlbanding/ |title=NIOSH Control Banding |accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health}}</ref>
A single ''control'' technology or strategy is matched with a single ''band'', or range of exposures (e.g. 1-10 milligrams per cubic meter) for a particular class of chemicals (e.g. skin irritants, reproductive hazards).
Here is an example of four control bands developed for [[inhalation]] hazards.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Band no. ! Hazard Group ! Exposure Concentration ! Control Strategy |- | 1 | Skin and eye irritants | <1–10 mg/m<sup>3</sup> dust, or >50 to 500 [[Parts per million|ppm]] [[vapor]] | General [[ventilation (architecture)|ventilation]] and good [[industrial hygiene]] practices. |- | 2 | Harmful on single exposure | >0.1 to 1 mg/m<sup>3</sup> dust or >5 to 550 ppm vapor | Local exhaust ventilation |- | 3 | Severely irritating and corrosive | >0.01 to 0.1 mg/m<sup>3</sup> dust or <0.5 to 5 ppm vapor | Process enclosure, an engineering control |- | 4 | Very toxic on single exposure, reproductive hazard, sensitizer | <0.01 mg/m<sup>3</sup> dust or <0.5 ppm vapor | Seek expert advice |}
In the [[United Kingdom]], the [[Health and Safety Executive]] (HSE) has developed a comprehensive control banding model called ''COSHH Essentials'' ([[COSHH]] stands for ''control of substances hazardous to health.)''
The use of control banding strategies has become very popular in the pharmaceutical industry<ref>{{cite web |author=Naumann, B. |title=Control Banding in the Pharmaceutical Industry |url=http://www.aioh.org.au/downloads/documents/ControlBandingBNaumann.pdf |work= |publisher= |date= |accessdate=October 16, 2009}}</ref> where early stage development compounds may have little or no toxicology data.
==Limitations of Control Banding== Control banding is not without limitations and still requires professional knowledge and experience to verify that the control measures specified have been properly installed, maintained, and used. Controls should be validated prior to use by either using substance specific industrial hygiene methods or performing surrogate monitoring.
==See also== *[[Hierarchy of hazard control]] *[[Occupational exposure banding]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/ctrlbanding/ NIOSH Safety and Health Topic: Control Banding] * [http://www.coshh-essentials.org.uk/ ''COSHH Essentials''] * [http://ioha.net/control-banding/ IOHA Control Banding] * [http://www.baua.de/cae/servlet/contentblob/674200/publicationFile/48355/workplace-control-scheme.pdf BAuA: Easy-to-use control scheme for hazardous substances (EMKG)] * [http://www.reach-clp-helpdesk.de/reach/en/Exposure/Exposure.html BAuA: EMKG-Expo-Tool for Exposure Assessment (Workers)] * [https://www.stoffenmanager.nl/ Stoffenmanager] * [http://www.control-banding.net/ Chemwatch - Control Banding Risk Assessment Tool]
[[Category:Hazard analysis]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Public health]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Guyanese emigrants to the United Kingdom]]; added [[Category:Guyanese emigrants to England]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox medical person | honorific_prefix = | name = Daphne Steele | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = {{birth year|1929}} | birth_place = [[Essequibo (colony)|Essequibo]] | death_date = {{death year and age|2004|1929}} | death_place = [[Ilkley]], [[West Yorkshire]] | nationality = [[Guyana|Guyanese]] | citizenship = | education = | occupation = [[Nurse]] | years_active = | known_for = First Black [[Matron]] in the [[National Health Service]] | relations = [[Carmen Munroe]] (sister) | profession = | field = | work_institutions = | signature = }} '''Daphne Steele''' (1929–2004) was a [[Guyana|Guyanese]] [[nurse]], who in 1964 became the first [[Black people|Black]] [[Matron]] in the [[National Health Service]].
==Early life== Daphne Steele was born in 1929 in the Dutch colony of [[Essequibo (colony)|Essequibo]] (now part of [[Guyana]]) as the eldest of nine children.<ref name="employers"/> Her younger sister Carmen Steele later became better known as the actress [[Carmen Munroe]].<ref name="life"/> While her mother stayed at home, her father worked as a [[pharmacist]] who travelled around the colony to work.<ref name="employers">{{cite web|title=BME Trailblazers in the NHS: Daphne Steele|url=http://www.nhsemployers.org/~/media/Employers/Publications/BME-trailblazers-in-the-NHS-Daphne-Steele.pdf|publisher=NHS Employers|accessdate=17 November 2017}}</ref> The family were sufficiently well off to be able to afford servants to clean the family house.<ref name="life">{{cite book|last1=Sewell|first1=T|title="All aboard we're getting a life"|date=1998|publisher=Voice Enterprises|location=London|isbn=1872841007|pages=55-57}}</ref>
==Medical career== She underwent training in [[nursing]] and [[midwifery]] at the public hospital in [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]] in 1945. She emigrated to the United Kingdom in 1951,<ref name="employers"/> as part of the British Government seeking to recruit people to the new [[National Health Service]] (NHS).<ref name="argus"/> The journey took 14 days, and she arrived in [[Plymouth]], [[Devon]]. She was surprised when a white man took her luggage for her, as in her native country, white men only worked in managerial roles.<ref name="life"/> Steele was placed on a fast-track scheme in [[Balham]], [[South London]], at the St. James's Hospital.<ref name="employers"/> She found the discipline to be akin to being in the military, which extended to the nurses' home where she lived. Steele also witnessed the [[racism]] of white colleagues and from patients, but tried to be friendly to avoid this personally. She later recalled that her Jamaican colleagues were skilled in "cussing" out particularly nasty patients.<ref name="life"/>
She moved to the United States in 1955, where she worked at a hospital in [[New Jersey]], before moving back to the UK in 1960 where she was stationed at [[RAF Brize Norton]]. She later moved to Manchester, where she was employed as a Deputy [[Matron]] at a [[nursing home]]. When it was announced that the home was closing,<ref name="employers"/> an Irish Matron suggested that Steele should also apply to become a Matron. So in 1964, she was appointed as Matron at St. Winifred's Hospital in [[Ilkley]], [[West Yorkshire]]. This was the first time that a [[Black people|Black person]] had been appointed as a Matron anywhere in the NHS.<ref name="life"/> The news of the appointment made news worldwide,<ref name="employers"/> with Steele receiving around 350 letters from well-wishers.<ref name="argus"/> After the hospital closed in 1971, Steele became a [[health visitor]] at [[Leeds University]].<ref name="employers"/>
==Later life== Following retirement, Steele volunteered for a variety of organisations, including for [[Soroptimist International]] and became vice-president of the Association of Guyanese Nurses and Allied Professionals (AGNAP). She was a devoted [[Methodist]].<ref name="employers"/> In 2001, the [[Guyanese High Commissioner to the United Kingdom]] awarded Steele a certificate in recognition of her medical achievements.<ref name="argus">{{cite news|title=Ex-matron's work earns award from Guyana|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/8035998.Ex_matron_s_work_earns_award_from_Guyana/|accessdate=17 November 2017|work=Telegraph and Argus|date=25 October 2001}}</ref> Steele died in 2004. In her memory, AGNAP renamed their annual health talk in 2013 to the Daphne Steele Memorial Lecture.<ref name="employers"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Steele, Daphne}}
[[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:People from Essequibo Islands-West Demerara]] [[Category:Guyanese Methodists]] [[Category:Guyanese emigrants to England]] [[Category:Guyanese nurses]] [[Category:Women nurses]]

The documented history of philosophy is often said to begin with the notable death of [[Socrates]]. Since that time, there have been many other noteworthy '''deaths of philosophers'''.
*435 BCE According to legend, [[Empedocles]] leapt to his death into the crater of [[Mount Etna|Etna]]. *420 BCE According to some reports, [[Protagoras]] died in a shipwreck. *399 BCE [[Socrates]], condemned to death for corrupting the young, drank hemlock amongst his friends as described in Plato’s ''[[Phaedo]]''. *348 BCE [[Plato]] either died while being serenaded by a Thracian flute-playing girl, or at a wedding feast. *338 BCE According to legend, [[Isocrates]] starved himself to death. *323 BCE Accounts differ regarding the death of [[Diogenes of Sinope]]. He is alleged to have died from eating raw octopus, from being bitten by a dog, and from holding his breath. He left instructions for his corpse to be left outside the city walls as a feast for the animals and birds. *320 BCE Ancient sources tell us that Nicocreon the tyrant had [[Anaxarchus]] pounded to death in a mortar with iron pestles; Anaxarchus is said to have made light of the punishment. *314 BCE [[Xenocrates]] died when he hit his head after tripping over a bronze pot. *270 BCE [[Epicurus]] died of kidney stones. *262 BCE [[Zeno of Citium]] founder of the [[stoicism|Stoic]] philosophical school tripped and broke his toe and then died from holding his breath. *207 BCE [[Chrysippus]] is said to have died from laughter after giving wine to his donkey and seeing it attempt to eat figs. *52 BCE [[Lucretius]] is alleged to have killed himself after being driven mad by taking a love potion. *65 CE [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]] was forced to commit suicide after falling out with Emperor Nero. *415 [[Hypatia]] was killed by a mob of Christians. *430 [[Saint Augustine]] died in Hippo while the city was under siege by the [[Vandals]]. *526 [[Boethius]] was strangled on the orders of the Ostrogoth king Theodoric by whom he was employed. *1141 [[Judah Halevi]] was killed on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem. *1180 [[Abraham ibn Daud]] was martyred. *1277 [[Pope John XXI]] (usually identified with the logician [[Peter of Spain (author)|Peter of Spain]]) was killed by the collapse of a roof. *1284 [[Siger of Brabant]] was stabbed to death by his clerk. *1415 [[Jan Hus]] was executed at the Council of Constance. *1487 [[John Argyropoulos]] supposedly died of consuming too much [[watermelon]]. *1535 [[Thomas More]] was executed by beheading in 1535 after he had fallen out of favour with King Henry VIII. *1572 [[Girolamo Maggi]] was executed by strangulation on the orders of a prison captain in Constantinople; Maggi had been incarcerated after being arrested during the Turkish siege of Famagusta. *1572 [[Peter Ramus]] was killed in the St. Bartholomew’s Day Massacre. *1600 [[Giordano Bruno]] was burnt by the Inquisition. *1619 [[Lucilio Vanini]] was also burnt by the Inquisition. *1626 [[Francis Bacon]] died of pneumonia, contracted while stuffing snow into a chicken as an experiment in refrigeration. *1640 [[Uriel da Costa]], after being beaten and trampled by a religious group he had offended, went home and shot himself. *1650 [[René Descartes]] was killed by a cold acquired through his rising early to instruct Queen Christina of Sweden. *1677 [[Baruch Spinoza]] died of a pulmonary ailment, thought to be either tuberculosis or silicosis, brought on by inhaling glass dust while working as a lens grinder. *1683 [[Algernon Sidney]] was executed for treason. *1716 [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] died in Hanover on 14 November 1716 after a prolonged case of arthritis and gout. The only one to attend his funeral was his secretary, [[Johann Georg von Eckhart]]. *1794 The [[Marquis de Condorcet]] died in prison. *1814 [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte]] died of typhus in Berlin, during the campaign against Napoleon. *1831 [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]] died of a gastrointestinal disease during a cholera outbreak in Berlin. *1837 [[Giacomo Leopardi]] died in Naples during a cholera epidemic, maybe by pulmonary edema. *1866 [[William Whewell]] was thrown from his horse and sustained fatal injuries. *1876 [[Philipp Mainländer]] hanged himself in his residence in Offenbach, using a pile of copies of ''The Philosophy of Redemption'' as a platform. *1882 [[William Jevons]] was drowned while bathing. *1900 [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] died after a mental breakdown. *1901 [[Paul Rée]] fell to his death from a mountain. *1903 [[Otto Weininger]] committed suicide by shooting himself. *1906 [[Ludwig Boltzmann]] hanged himself. *1910 [[Carlo Michelstaedter]] killed himself with a pistol he had in his house. *1911 [[Paul Lafargue]] died with his wife, Laura Marx, in a suicide pact. *1915 [[Emil Lask]] was killed in action as soldier in World War I. *1917 [[Adolf Reinach]] fell outside Diksmuide in Flanders during World War I. *1928 [[Alexander Bogdanov]] died as a result of one of his experiments in blood transfusion. *1930 [[Frank P. Ramsey]] died after "contracting [[jaundice]]" at the age of 26. (Jaundice by itself is not a cause of death but instead indicates hemolytic or hepatic disease.) *1931 [[Jacques Herbrand]] died in a mountaineering accident in the Alps at the age of 23. *1936 [[Moritz Schlick]] was murdered by an insane student. *1937 [[Gustav Shpet]] was executed after being accused of involvement in an anti-[[Soviet]] organization. *1937 [[Antonio Gramsci]] died during his imprisonment by [[Benito Mussolini]]. *1939 [[Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz]] committed suicide by taking an overdose of [[Barbital|Veronal]] and trying to slit his wrists a day after the Soviet invasion of Poland; it was planned to be a joint suicide with a close friend of his but she survived the attempt. *1940 [[Walter Benjamin]] committed suicide at the Spanish-French border, after attempting to flee from the Nazis. *1940 [[Leon Trotsky]] was assassinated on Stalin's orders in Mexico, by Soviet agent [[Ramón Mercader]], along with most of his family. *1941 [[Henri Bergson]] died of pneumonia in occupied Paris, which he supposedly contracted after standing in a queue for several hours in order to register as a Jew. *1941 [[Kurt Grelling]] was killed by the Nazis. *1941 [[Edith Stein]] died in a gas chamber in the Auschwitz concentration camp. *1943 [[Simone Weil]] starved herself to death. *1944 [[Jean Cavaillès]] was shot by the Gestapo. *1944 [[Marc Bloch]] was shot by the Gestapo for his work in the French Resistance. *1944 [[Giovanni Gentile]] was murdered by communist partisans. *1945 [[Dietrich Bonhoeffer]] was executed by hanging. *1945 [[Gerhard Gentzen]] was detained in a prison camp by the Russian forces, where he died of malnutrition. *1945 [[Ernst Bergmann (philosopher)|Ernst Bergmann]] committed suicide after the Allied forces captured Leipzig. *1945 [[Johan Huizinga]] died in De Steeg in Gelderland, near Arnhem, where he was held in detention by the Nazis. *1945 [[Miki Kiyoshi]] died in prison; he had been imprisoned after helping a friend on the run from the authorities. *1948 [[Mohandas Gandhi]] was shot and killed by a Hindu zealot. *1954 [[Alan Turing]] ate a cyanide-poisoned apple. He was believed at the time to have committed suicide due to chemical depression, but his death was possibly just an accident.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-18561092 "Alan Turing: Inquest's suicide verdict 'not supportable'" by Roland Pease (26 June 2012)]</ref> *1960 [[Albert Camus]] died in an automobile accident. *1961 [[Maurice Merleau-Ponty]] died of a stroke while preparing a lecture on [[Descartes]]. *1969 [[Theodor Adorno]] developed heart palpitations after attempting to climb a 3000-metre mountain, and subsequently suffered a heart attack. *1971 [[Richard Montague]] was beaten to death, presumably by a male prostitute. *1973 [[Amílcar Cabral]] was assassinated while fighting for the independence of Portuguese colonies in Africa. *1977 [[Jan Patočka]] died of an [[apoplexy]] after having been interrogated by the Czechoslovak secret police for eleven hours. *1978 [[Kurt Gödel]] starved himself to death by refusing to eat for fear of being poisoned. *1979 [[Evald Ilyenkov]] committed suicide. *1979 [[Nicos Poulantzas]] committed suicide by jumping out of the twentieth floor of his apartment building. *1980 [[Roland Barthes]] was struck in the street by a laundry van after leaving a luncheon with French President François Mitterrand. *1983 [[Arthur Koestler]] committed joint suicide with his third wife, Cynthia, by taking an overdose of drugs after a painful struggle with disease. *1984 [[Michel Foucault]] was the first high-profile French personality to die of AIDS after contracting HIV. *1994 [[David Stove]] committed suicide by hanging himself after a painful struggle with disease. *1994 [[Sarah Kofman]] committed suicide on Nietzsche’s birthday. *1994 [[Guy Debord]] committed suicide by shooting himself after a painful struggle with polyneuritis. *1995 [[Gilles Deleuze]] committed suicide by jumping out of his fourth-story apartment window. *1998 [[Dimitris Liantinis]] committed suicide on the mountains of [[Taygetus|Taygetos]]. *2001 [[David Lewis (philosopher)|David Lewis]] died of diabetes related complications. *2004 [[Jacques Derrida]] died of pancreatic cancer. *2007 [[André Gorz]] committed joint suicide with his wife by lethal injection.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Ava Chitwood, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=UJ6_jlsj0yQC&dq=empedocles+heraclitus&source=gbs_navlinks_s Death by Philosophy]'', University of Michigan Press, 2004. * [[Simon Critchley]], ''Book of Dead Philosophers'', Vintage, 2009. * David Palfrey, [http://www.britac.ac.uk/sites/default/files/01-palfrey.pdf "How Philosophers Die"], ''British Academy Review'', Issue 10 (2007) * [[Anthony Quinton]], 'Deaths of philosophers', ''[[The Oxford Companion to Philosophy]]'', Oxford, 1995, 2005.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Deaths Of Philosophers}} [[Category:Death-related lists|Philosophers]] [[Category:Lists of philosophers]]

'''Giuseppe Vincenzo Ciaccio''' (15 October 1824 in [[Catanzaro]] – 15 June 1901 in [[Bologna]]) was an Italian [[anatomist]] and [[histologist]]. His name is associated with accessory [[lacrimal gland]]s known as "[[Ciaccio's glands]]".<ref>[http://www.mondofacto.com/facts/dictionary?Ciaccio's+glands Mondofacto Dictionary] Ciaccio glands</ref>
In 1845, he earned his degree in medicine and [[surgery]] in [[Naples]], afterwards opening a medical practice in [[Catanzaro]], where in 1855 he attained the chair of theoretical surgery and [[obstetrics]] at the royal university-school. In 1860 he relocated to [[Turin]], subsequently receiving a scholarship to study and work abroad. In [[London]], he met with [[Thomas Spencer Wells]] (1818-1897) and [[Lionel Smith Beale]] (1828-1906), who was an important influence to Ciaccio in his decision to dedicate himself to [[microscopic anatomy]]. Following his stay in England, he traveled to [[Berlin]], where he attended lectures by [[Rudolf Virchow]] (1821-1902) and performed histological studies of [[Pacinian corpuscle]]s in the laboratory of [[Wilhelm Kühne]] (1837-1900).
In 1865, he was named professor of microscopic anatomy at the [[University of Naples]], and two years later served as professor of experimental [[physiology]] at the [[University of Parma]]. From 1870 he was associated with the [[University of Bologna]], working as a professor of [[comparative anatomy]] and [[histology]].<ref>[http://www.zeno.org/Pagel-1901/A/Ciaccio,+Giuseppe+Vincenzo Pagel: Biographical Dictionary] excellent doctors of the nineteenth century. Berlin, Vienna, 1901, col 325-326.</ref>
In the fields of anatomy and histology, he is known for studies involving the finer structure of the [[eye]] (microscopic investigations of the [[conjunctiva]], [[cornea]] and [[Vitreous humour|vitreous]]). He also made contributions involving research of peripheral [[nerve fiber]] terminations in vertebrates (e.g. [[torpedo fish]]).
== Selected publications == The following are a few of Ciaccio's many publications in anatomy and histology. * ''Intorno al finale distribuimento de' nervi nell'organo elettrico della torpedine'' (Torpedo Narke, Risso), ibid.., II (1870)., pp. 5–9 - About the final distribution of nerves in the [[Electric organ (biology)|electric organ]]s of torpedo fish. * ''Osservazioni intorno alla struttura della congiuntiva umana'', (ibid., s.1, IV [1874], p. 469-524) - Remarks about the structure of the human [[conjunctiva]]. * ''Osservazioni intorno alla membrana del Descemet e al suo endotelio, con una descrizione anatomica dell'occhio della talpa europea'', ibid., V (1875), pp. 501–516, e 2 tavole di 20figure - Observations on the [[Descemet membrane]] and its [[endothelium]], with an anatomical description of the eye of the [[European mole]]. * ''Osservazioni istologiche intorno alla terminazione delle fibre nervose motive ne' muscoli striati delle torpedini, del topo casalingo e del ratto albino condizionati col doppio cloruro d'oro e cadmio'', ibid., IV (1882), pp. 821–830, e 2 tavole di 24figure - Observations involving motor nerve terminations in the [[striated muscle tissue|striated muscle]] of torpedo fish, etc. * ''Della minuta fabbrica degli occhi dei Ditteri'', (ibid., s.4, VI [1884], pp. 605–660) - On the minute fabric involving the eyes of [[Diptera]]. * ''Osservazioni microscopiche intorno agli organi elettrici delle torpedini'', (ibid., s.5, VII [1899], p. 4tavole and 587-619). Microscopical observations involving the electric organs of torpedo fish.
== References == * [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giuseppe-vincenzo-ciaccio_(Dizionario-Biografico)/ Treccani.it] Biographical Dictionary of Italian - Volume 25 (1981) by Renato G. Mazzolini (biography with extensive bibliography) {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ciaccio, Giuseppe Vincenzo}} [[Category:Histologists]] [[Category:Italian anatomists]] [[Category:Italian pathologists]] [[Category:1901 deaths]] [[Category:1824 births]] [[Category:University of Bologna faculty]] [[Category:University of Parma faculty]] [[Category:People from Catanzaro]]

revision.comment: /* Fast followers */ added EPR column, and populated with some EHR providers.
revision.text:
'''Global Digital Exemplar''' ('''GDE''') is a knowledge sharing platform developed by [[NHS England]]. The programme is to enable "digitally advanced"<ref>{{cite web |title=NHS England » Global Digital Exemplars |url=https://www.england.nhs.uk/digitaltechnology/info-revolution/exemplars/ |website=www.england.nhs.uk |accessdate=8 July 2018 |date=2 May 2018}}</ref> [[NHS trust]]s to share knowledge with other NHS trusts. Specifically knowledge gained during the implementation of IT systems, and especially experience from introducing [[electronic health record]] (EHR) systems. The GDE project is expected to last two to three and a half years; with the most digitally advanced trusts on the shorter time scale.<ref name="NHSEblog-Nov17">{{cite web |last1=Swindells |first1=Matthew |last2=Smart |first2=Will |title=Progressing the acute Global Digital Exemplar |url=https://www.england.nhs.uk/blog/progressing-the-acute-global-digital-exemplar/ |website=www.england.nhs.uk |publisher=NHS England |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref>
Four rounds of exemplars have been announced so far — two waves of acute trust GDEs, and one wave each of ambulance trusts, and mental health trusts. In addition, eighteen acute trust "fast followers" have been partnered with the acute trusts.<ref name="BJHC-Sep17">{{cite news |title=Eighteen NHS trusts confirmed as 'fast followers' to digital exemplars |journal=British Journal of Healthcare Computing |date=11 September 2017 |url=https://www.bj-hc.co.uk/eighteen-nhs-trusts-confirmed-fast-followers-digital-exemplars |accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref>
Each GDE will receive "up to £10 million" to spend on digital projects.<ref name="HSJ-July17">{{cite news |last1=Heather |first1=Ben |title=Flagship digital fund finally reaches 'exemplar' trusts |journal=Health Service Journal |date=3 July 2017 |url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/technology-and-innovation/flagship-digital-fund-finally-reaches-exemplar-trusts/7019136.article |accessdate=8 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The funding must be matched locally, but not necessarily in cash.<ref name="NHSEblog-Nov17" />
==Acute exemplars== The first twelve exemplars were announced in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=New plans to expand the use of digital technology across the NHS|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/new-plans-to-expand-the-use-of-digital-technology-across-the-nhs|accessdate=2 July 2018|work=gov.uk|publisher=Department of Health and The Rt Hon Jeremy Hunt MP|ref=GDE}}</ref> A second wave added another four in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stevens|first1=Laura|title=Four more acute global digital exemplars confirmed by NHS England|url=https://www.digitalhealth.net/2017/03/four-more-acute-global-digital-exemplars-confirmed-by-nhs-england/|accessdate=2 July 2018|work=Digital Health|publisher=Digital Health|date=31 March 2017}}</ref>
Although NHS England refers to this grouping of exemplars as "acute", a number of the hospitals operated by trusts within this group are [[Hospital#Specialised|specialised hospitals]]. Examples include, [[Alder Hey Children's Hospital]] and [[Western Eye Hospital]].
===North=== *[[Alder Hey Children's Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[City Hospitals Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust]] *[[Salford Royal NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]]
===Midlands and East=== *[[Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Luton and Dunstable University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[West Suffolk NHS Foundation Trust]]
===London=== *[[Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust]] and [[Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust]] (as a joint Exemplar)
===South=== *[[Oxford University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[University Hospitals Bristol NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust]]
===Fast followers=== There are eighteen acute "fast follower" trusts, each of which has been partnered with an acute GDE.<ref name="BJHC-Sep17" />

==Ambulance exemplars== As of July 2018, there are three [[Emergency medical services in the United Kingdom|ambulance trust]] exemplars.<ref>{{cite web |title=NHS England » Ambulance Global Digital Exemplars |url=https://www.england.nhs.uk/digitaltechnology/info-revolution/exemplars/ambulance-global-digital-exemplars/ |website=www.england.nhs.uk |accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> *[[South Central Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[West Midlands Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[North East Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust]]
==Mental health exemplars== There are currently seven [[mental health trust]] GDEs.<ref>{{cite web |title=NHS England » Mental Health Global Digital Exemplars |url=https://www.england.nhs.uk/digitaltechnology/info-revolution/exemplars/mental-health-global-digital-exemplars/ |website=www.england.nhs.uk |accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> *[[Berkshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Birmingham and Solihull Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Mersey Care NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Northumberland, Tyne and Wear NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust]] *[[Worcestershire Health and Care NHS Trust]]
