''Scientific American''.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=FW|last2=Rothfels|first2=CJ|last3=Melkonian|first3=M|last4=Villarreal|first4=JC|last5=Stevenson|first5=DW|last6=Graham|first6=SW|last7=Wong|first7=GK|last8=Mathews|first8=S|last9=Pryer|first9=KM|title=The origin and evolution of phototropins.|journal=Frontiers in Plant Science|date=2015|volume=6|pages=637|doi=10.3389/fpls.2015.00637|pmid=26322073|pmc=4532919}}</ref> *transfer of a [[cysteine synthase]] from a bacterium into [[herbivore|phytophagous]] [[mite]]s and [[Lepidoptera]] allowing the detoxification of [[cyanogenic glycosides|cyanogenic glucosides]] produced by host plants.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wybouw|first=Nicky|last2=Dermauw|first2=Wannes|last3=Tirry|first3=Luc|last4=Stevens|first4=Christian|last5=Grbić|first5=Miodrag|last6=Feyereisen|first6=René|last7=Leeuwen|first7=Thomas Van|date=2014-04-24|title=A gene horizontally transferred from bacteria protects arthropods from host plant cyanide poisoning|url=https://elifesciences.org/content/3/e02365v2|journal=eLife|language=en|volume=3|pages=e02365|doi=10.7554/eLife.02365|issn=2050-084X|pmc=4011162|pmid=24843024}}</ref> *The [[LINE1]] sequence has transferred from humans to the [[gonorrhea]] bacteria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2011/02/16/gonorrhea-has-picked-up-human-dna-and-thats-just-the-beginning/|title=Gonorrhea has picked up human DNA (and that's just the beginning)|last=Yong|first=Ed|date=2011-02-16|publisher=National Geographic|language=English|access-date=2016-07-14}}</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Agrobacterium]], a bacterium well known for its ability to transfer DNA between itself and plants. *[[Endogenous retrovirus]] *[[Genetically modified organism]] *[[Inferring horizontal gene transfer]] *[[Integron]] *[[Mobile genetic elements]] *[[Phylogenetic network]] *[[Phylogenetic tree]] *[[Provirus]] *[[Reassortment]] *[[Retrotransposon]] *[[Symbiogenesis]] *[[Tree of life (biology)]] *[[Xenobiology]] {{div col end}}
==Sources and notes==<!-- GenomeRes9:689 --> {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== {{Scholia|topic}} *[[:Citizendium:Horizontal gene transfer]] *[[:Citizendium:Horizontal gene transfer in prokaryotes]] *[[:Citizendium:Horizontal gene transfer in plants]] *[[:Citizendium:Horizontal gene transfer (History)]] *{{cite journal |last1= Gyles |first1= C |last2= Boerlin |first2= P |date= Mar 2014 |title= Horizontally transferred genetic elements and their role in pathogenesis of bacterial disease |url= |journal= Vet Pathol |volume= 51 |issue= 2 |pages= 328–40 |doi=10.1177/0300985813511131 |pmid=24318976}} *[http://vme.net/hgt/ – Papers by Dr Michael Syvanen on Horizontal Gene Transfer] *{{cite journal |vauthors=Salzberg SL, White O, Peterson J, Eisen JA |title=Microbial genes in the human genome: lateral transfer or gene loss? |journal=Science |volume=292 |issue=5523 |pages=1903–6 |date=June 2001 |pmid=11358996 |doi=10.1126/science.1061036 |url=http://www.cbcb.umd.edu/~salzberg/docs/ScienceLateralTransfer.pdf|bibcode= 2001Sci...292.1903S|quote=About 40 genes were found to be exclusively shared by humans and bacteria and are candidate examples of horizontal transfer from bacteria to vertebrates. Gene loss combined with sample size effects and evolutionary rate variation provide an alternative, more biologically plausible explanation}} *{{cite journal |last=Qi|first=Z|author2=Cui, Y |author3=Fang, W |author4=Ling, L |author5= Chen, R |title=Autosomal similarity revealed by eukaryotic genomic comparison.|journal=Journal of biological physics|date=January 2004|volume=30|issue=4|pages=305–12|pmid=23345874|doi=10.1007/s10867-004-0996-0 |pmc=3456315}} *{{cite journal |author=Woese CR |title=On the evolution of cells |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=99 |issue=13 |pages=8742–7 |date=June 2002 |pmid=12077305 |pmc=124369 |doi=10.1073/pnas.132266999 |bibcode= 2002PNAS...99.8742W}} This article seeks to shift the emphasis in early [[phylogenetics|phylogenic adaptation]] from vertical to horizontal gene transfer. He uses the term "Darwinian Threshold" for the time of major transition of evolutionary mechanisms from mostly horizontal to mostly vertical transfer, and the "origin of speciation". *{{cite journal |vauthors=Snel B, Bork P, Huynen MA |title=Genome phylogeny based on gene content |journal=Nat. Genet. |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=108–10 |date=January 1999 |pmid=9916801 |doi=10.1038/5052}} This article proposes using the presence or absence of a set of genes to infer phylogenies, in order to avoid confounding factors such as horizontal gene transfer. *''Webfocus in Nature with free review articles [http://www.nature.com/nrmicro/focus/genetransfer/index.html]'' *{{cite journal |vauthors=Patil PB, Sonti RV |title=Variation suggestive of horizontal gene transfer at a lipopolysaccharide (lps) biosynthetic locus in ''Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae'', the bacterial leaf blight pathogen of rice |journal=BMC Microbiol. |volume=4|pages=40 |date=October 2004 |pmid=15473911 |pmc=524487 |doi=10.1186/1471-2180-4-40 |issue=1}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Jin G, Nakhleh L, Snir S, Tuller T |title=Maximum likelihood of phylogenetic networks |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=22 |issue=21 |pages=2604–11 |date=November 2006 |pmid=16928736 |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btl452}} for a technique to decrease the impact of HGT events on maximum likelihood cladistical analyses. *[http://www.esalenctr.org/display/confpage.cfm?confid=10&pageid=105&pgtype=1 Horizontal Gene Transfer – A New Paradigm for Biology] *[https://web.archive.org/web/19990220101406/http://opbs.okstate.edu/%7Emelcher/MG/MGW3/MG334.html Horizontal Gene Transfer (page 334 of Molecular Genetics by Ulrich Melcher)] *[http://www.sci.sdsu.edu/~smaloy/MicrobialGenetics/topics/genetic-exchange/exchange/exchange.html Horizontal Gene Transfer at sciences.sdsu.edu] *{{cite journal |vauthors=Jain R, Rivera MC, Lake JA |title=Horizontal gene transfer among genomes: The complexity hypothesis |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=96 |issue=7 |pages=3801–6 |date=March 1999 |pmid=10097118 |pmc=22375 |doi= 10.1073/pnas.96.7.3801|url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10097118|bibcode= 1999PNAS...96.3801J}} *[http://www.stat.rice.edu/~mathbio/Ochman2000.pdf PDF article on Horizontal Gene Transfer] *[http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1999/07/12/the-demon-in-the-freezer The New Yorker, July 12, 1999, pp. 44–61] "Smallpox knows how to make a mouse protein. How did smallpox learn that? 'The poxviruses are promiscuous at capturing genes from their hosts,' Esposito said. 'It tells you that smallpox was once inside a mouse or some other small rodent.'" *{{cite journal |vauthors=Szpirer C, Top E, Couturier M, Mergeay M |title=Retrotransfer or gene capture: a feature of conjugative plasmids, with ecological and evolutionary significance |journal=Microbiology |volume=145 |issue=Pt 12 |pages=3321–9 |date=1 December 1999|pmid=10627031 |url=http://mic.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/145/12/3321 |doi= 10.1099/00221287-145-12-3321}} *[http://www.gmo-safety.eu/topics/3?mode=prj GMO Safety: Results of research into horizontal gene transfer] Can transgenes from genetically modified plants be absorbed by micro-organisms and spread in this way? *{{cite journal |vauthors=Whitaker JW, McConkey GA, Westhead DR |title=The transferome of metabolic genes explored: analysis of the horizontal transfer of enzyme encoding genes in unicellular eukaryotes |journal=[[Genome Biology]] |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=R36 |year=2009 |pmid=19368726 |pmc=2688927 |doi=10.1186/gb-2009-10-4-r36 |url=http://genomebiology.com/content/10/4/R36}}
{{Genetic recombination}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Horizontal Gene Transfer}} [[Category:Antibiotic resistance]] [[Category:Genetics]] [[Category:Microbial population biology]]

{{Infobox diagnostic | name = Insulin tolerance test | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | purpose = assess pituitary function/ adrenal function | test of = | based on = | synonyms = | reference_range = | calculator = | DiseasesDB = <!--{{DiseasesDB2|numeric_id}}--> | ICD10 = <!--{{ICD10|Group|Major|minor|LinkGroup|LinkMajor}} or {{ICD10PCS|code|char1/char2/char3/char4}}--> | ICD9 = | ICDO = | MedlinePlus = <!--article_number--> | eMedicine = <!--article_number--> | MeshID = | OPS301 = <!--{{OPS301|code}}--> | LOINC = <!--{{LOINC|code}}--> }} An '''insulin tolerance test''' ('''ITT''') is a medical diagnostic procedure during which [[insulin]] is injected into a patient's vein, after which blood glucose is measured at regular intervals. This procedure is performed to assess [[pituitary]] function, [[adrenal]] function, and sometimes for other purposes. An ITT is usually ordered and interpreted by [[endocrinologist]]s.
Insulin injections are intended to induce extreme [[hypoglycemia]] below 2.2 mmol/l (40 mg/dl). Patient must have symptomatic neuroglycopenia to trigger counter-regulatory cascade. Glucose levels below 2.2 mmol/L are insufficient absent symptoms. The brain must register low glucose levels. In response, [[adrenocorticotropic hormone]] (ACTH) and [[growth hormone]] (GH) are released as a part of the stress mechanism. ACTH elevation causes the [[adrenal cortex]] to release [[cortisol]]. Normally, both cortisol and GH serve as [[counterregulatory hormone]]s, opposing the action of insulin, i.e. acting against the hypoglycemia.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Greenwood FC, Landon J, Stamp TC |title=The plasma sugar, free fatty acid, cortisol, and growth hormone response to insulin. I. In control subjects |journal=J Clin Invest |volume=45 |pages=429– |year=1965 |doi=10.1172/JCI105357 |pmid=5937021 |issue=4 |pmc=292717 }}</ref>
Thus ITT is considered to be the [[gold standard (test)|gold standard]] for assessing the integrity of the [[hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis]]. Sometimes ITT is performed to assess the peak adrenal capacity, e.g. before [[surgery]]. It is assumed that the ability to respond to insulin induced hypoglycemia translates into appropriate cortisol rise in the stressful event of acute illness or major surgery.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Plumpton FS, Besser GM |title=The adrenocortical response to surgery and insulin-induced hypoglycaemia in corticosteroid-treated and normal subjects |journal=Br J Surg |volume=56 |pages=216–219 |year=1969 |doi=10.1002/bjs.1800560315 |pmid=5776687 |issue=3 }}</ref>
This test is potentially very dangerous and must be undertaken with great care, because it can [[iatrogenesis|iatrogenically]] induce the equivalent of a [[diabetic coma]]. A health professional must attend it at all times.
Other provocation tests which cause much less release of growth hormone include the use of [[glucagon]], [[arginine]] and [[clonidine]].
==Side effects== Side effects include sweating, palpitations, loss of consciousness and rarely convulsions due to severe hypoglycemia which may cause coma. If extreme symptoms are present, glucose should be given [[intravenous]]ly. In subjects with no adrenal reserve an [[Addisonian crisis]] may occur. For cortisol stimulation, the [[ACTH stimulation test]] has much less risk.
==Contraindications== * This test should not be performed on children outside a specialist [[pediatric]] endocrine unit. * [[Ischemic heart disease]] * [[Epilepsy]] * Severe [[panhypopituitarism]], [[hypoadrenalism]] * [[Hypothyroidism]] impairs the GH and cortisol response. Patients should have corticosteroid replacement commenced prior to thyroxine as the latter has been reported to precipitate an Addisonian crisis with dual deficiency. If adrenal insufficiency is confirmed, the need for a repeat ITT may need to be reconsidered after 3 months thyroxine therapy.
==Interpretation==
The test cannot be interpreted unless hypoglycaemia (< 2.2 mmol/L (or) < 40 mg/dl) is achieved.
===Hypopituitarism=== An adequate cortisol response is defined as a rise to greater than 550 nmol/L. Patients with impaired cortisol responses (less than 550 but greater than 400 nmol/L) may only need steroid cover for major illnesses or stresses. An adequate GH response occurs with an absolute response exceeding 20 mU/L.
===Cushing's syndrome=== There will be a rise of less than 170 nmol/L above the fluctuations of basal levels of cortisol.
==See also== * [[ACTH stimulation test]] * [[Hypopituitarism]] * [[Triple bolus test]]

{{Infobox International Labour Organization convention |code= C38 |name= Invalidity Insurance (Agriculture) Convention, 1933 (shelved) |adopt= June 29, 1933 |force= July 18, 1937 |classify= Old-age, Invalidity and Survivors Benefit |subject= Social Security |prev= [[Invalidity Insurance (Industry, etc.) Convention, 1933 (shelved)]] |next= [[Survivors' Insurance (Industry, etc.) Convention, 1933 (shelved)]] |shelved= yes }} '''Invalidity Insurance (Agriculture) Convention, 1933 (shelved)''' is an [[International Labour Organization]] [[International Labour Organization#International Labour Conference|Convention]]. It was established in 1933:
Having decided upon the adoption of certain proposals with regard to compulsory invalidity insurance,...
== Modification == The concepts included in the convention were revised and included in ILO Convention C128, [[Invalidity, Old-Age and Survivors' Benefits Convention, 1967]]. == Ratifications== Prior to its being shelved, the convention had been ratified by ten states. == External links == *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:12100:0::NO:12100:P12100_INSTRUMENT_ID:312183:NO Text]. *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312183 Ratifications]. {{Infobox hospital | Name = Izmirlian Medical Center | Org/Group = [[Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin]] | Image = Izmirlian - Surp Nerses.jpg | Caption = | Logo = | Location = 6 Avetsis Aharonian street,
[[Kanaker-Zeytun District|Kanaker-Zeytun]], [[Yerevan]] | Region = | State = | Country = {{flag|Armenia}} | Coordinates= | Healthcare = | Type = | Speciality = Proctology, Urology, Gyneacolory, Cardiology, Orthopedics, Otorhinolaryngology, Plastic surgery, etc. | Emergency = | Affiliation= [[Yerevan State Medical University]] | Beds = 139 | Founded = 1986
2013 (refounded) | Closed = | Website = [http://izmirlianmedicalcenter.com/eng/index Official website] | Wiki-Links = |}} '''Izmirlian Medical Center''' ({{lang-hy|Իզմիրլյան բժշկական կենտրոն}}), is a medical center and a research foundation located in the [[Armenia]]n capital [[Yerevan]]. Opened in 1986, it is located in the Kanaker-Zeytun district and currently operates under the supervision of the [[Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin]].[http://www.armenianchurch.org/index.jsp?sid=1&id=16862&pid=16860 Surb Nerses Mets Medical Research Foundation] The '''Surb Nerses Mets Research and Education Center''' ({{lang-hy|Սուրբ Ներսես Մեծ գիտաբժշկական կենտրոն}}), operates within the medical center. ==History== The medical center-institute was originally opened in 1986 in the Nor Zeytun neighbourhood of Yerevan as a center of [[proctology]] named after L. Nazarov. Between 1998 and 2000, the center was redeveloped by the [[New York City|New York]]-based [[Armenian General Benevolent Union]] to include a section for [[plastic surgery]] and other surgical specialties. In 2000, the center was granted to the [[Mother See of Holy Etchmiadzin]] and renamed as ''Surb Nerses Mets Medical Center'', after the Catholicos of All Armenians [[St. Nerses I|Nerses I]] of the 4 the century. In 2013, the center was entirely redeveloped through donations from the ''Izmirlian Family Foundation''. US$12 million has been allocated for the redevelopment process and the construction of a new building. The hospital of the center was renamed in honor of benefactor Dikran Izmirlian. Other Armenian benefactors from [[Brazil]], United States and France have also contributed in the redevelopment of the center.[http://www.armenianchurch.org/index.jsp?sid=1&id=97&pid=4&lng=en Izmirlian Medical Center and St. Nerses the Great Medical Science Center] ==Services== With a capacity of 139 beds, currently the medical center-institute has 15 sections:[http://izmirlianmedicalcenter.com/eng/text/8/%D4%B8%D5%B6%D5%A4%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%B8%D6%82%D6%80-%D5%BF%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A5%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%BE%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6 General information] * [[Colorectal surgery|Coloproctology]] * General proctology * [[Orthopedic surgery|Orthopedics]] and sports [[traumatology]] * [[General surgery|General]] and [[laparoscopic surgery]] * [[Urology]] * [[Otorhinolaryngology]] / [[Plastic surgery|Plastic]], [[oral and maxillofacial surgery]] * [[Endoscopy]] and reconstructive [[gynaecology]] * [[Anesthesiology]], rehabilitation and [[Intensive Care Unit|ICU]] * [[Cardiac surgery]] * [[Cardiothoracic surgery]] * [[Vascular surgery]] * [[Robot-assisted surgery]] * [[Hematology]] * [[CT scan|Computerized axial tomography scan]] * [[Magnetic resonance imaging]] * Advisory diagnostic * Laboratory Researches in the center are mainly conducted in the fields of [[urology]], [[proctology]], [[gastroenterology]], etc. The center also hosts several conferences in urology throughout the year.[http://izmirlianmedicalcenter.com/en/%D5%BD%D5%B8%D6%82%D6%80%D5%A2-%D5%B6%D5%A5%D6%80%D5%BD%D5%A5%D5%BD-%D5%B4%D5%A5%D5%AE-%D5%A3%D5%AB%D5%BF%D5%A1%D5%AF%D6%80%D5%A9%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6-%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%B8%D5%B6/ Surb Nerses Mets Medical Research and Education Center] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|40|12|19|N|44|32|02|E|display=title}} {{Yerevan landmarks}} [[Category:Hospitals in Yerevan]] [[Category:Health in Armenia]] [[Category:Lists of buildings and structures in Armenia|Hospitals]]

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Janine O'Leary Cobb | image = JanineOLearyCobb.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = | birth_date = June 20, 1933 | birth_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | occupation = Author, health activist | nationality = Canadian | period = | genre = Women's Health | notableworks = ''Understanding Menopause'' and ''A Friend Indeed'' }}
'''Janine O'Leary Cobb''' is a women's health activist and educator, and the author of one of the first popular books on [[menopause]] intended for a mainstream audience, ''Understanding Menopause'' (first published in 1988, now in its 6th edition, published 2005).<ref>[https://www.amazon.ca/dp/1552636755 Understanding Menopause: Amazon.ca: Janine O'leary Cobb: Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Cobb is recognized widely as a pioneer in the [[women's health]] movement in [[North America]] and has won critical recognition for her work in the field.<ref>[http://www.womensenews.org/story/health/020426/menopause-study-ignites-interest-new-therapies Menopause Study Ignites Interest in New Therapies | Women's eNews<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://nwhn.org/honor30_cobb Janine O'Leary Cobb | National Women's Health Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.cwhn.ca/en/node/39522 Canadian Women's Health Publication Celebrates 20th Anniversary in Print! | Canadian Women's Health Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Congratulations,+Janine!-a0139566987 Congratulations, Janine! - Free Online Library<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1984 she founded the popular health newsletter, ''A Friend Indeed'', dedicated to highlighting the increasing medicalization of menopause, and to breaking the taboo of silence that still hung over many important women's health issues, such as [[menstruation]], menopause and [[breast cancer]].<ref>{{cite journal|pmc=1490529 | pmid=8431824 | volume=148 | issue=4 | title=Menopause comes out of the closet |date=February 1993 | journal=CMAJ | pages=613–5}}</ref> The publication continued to be released bi-monthly under the stewardship of other editors until 2006.<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/A+Friend+Indeed/publications.aspx?pageNumber=1 A Friend Indeed - Newspaper articles | Encyclopedia.com: Find newspaper articles!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Cobb was previously a professor with [[Vanier College]], Montreal and is currently a Board member with [[Breast Cancer Action Montreal]].<ref>[http://www.bcam.qc.ca/content/board-directors Board of Directors | Breast Cancer Action Montreal<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She is also a contributor to [[Our Bodies, Ourselves]], the groundbreaking women's health collective. She lives in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada.
==References== <references/>
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cobb, Janine}} [[Category:Canadian health and wellness writers]] [[Category:Canadian feminists]] [[Category:Writers from Montreal]] [[Category:Canadian women non-fiction writers]] [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} [[File:John Robert Hume (?). Oil painting. Wellcome V0017904.jpg|thumb|Portrait tentatively identified as John Robert Hume]] '''John Robert Hume''' (c.1781–1857) was a Scottish surgeon and physician. He is cited as an example of a 19th-century medical career that arrived at a high position in the profession, without early qualifications.<ref>{{cite book|author=John Shepherd|title=The Crimean Doctors: A History of the British Medical Services in the Crimean War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HpCgkcvNiLcC&pg=PA10|date=1 January 1991|publisher=Liverpool University Press|isbn=978-0-85323-107-3|page=10}}</ref>
==Early life and military service== Born in [[Renfrewshire]] in 1781 or 1782, he was the son of Joseph Hume, a medical practitioner at [[Hamilton, South Lanarkshire|Hamilton]]. He studied medicine at Glasgow in 1795, 1798, and at Edinburgh in 1796–7. He entered the medical service of the army as a hospital mate, was in Holland in 1799, and joined the [[92nd Regiment of Foot]] as assistant surgeon in 1800. He was in Egypt in 1801.<ref name="DNB">{{cite DNB|wstitle=Hume, John Robert|volume=28}}</ref><ref name="LC">{{cite web|url=http://studymore.org.uk/6biom.htm|title=Biographies of Medical Lunacy Commissioners1828-1912|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maltaramc.com/regsurg/h/humejr.html|title=maltaramc.com, ''Hume John Robert''|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref> In that campaign he served as surgeon on [[HMS Ceres (1781)|HMS ''Ceres'']].<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Edward Daniel Clarke]]|title=Travels in Various Countries of Europe, Asia and Africa: Greece, Egypt, and the Holy Land|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0rduMdSxVvsC&pg=PA419|year=1817|publisher=T. Cadell and W. Davies|page=419}}</ref> Some of his journals for his visit to [[Cyprus]] (including [[Larnaka]] and [[Limassol]]) were printed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/excerptacypriam00cobhgoog#page/n359/mode/2up|title=''Excerpta cypria''|last=Cobham|first=Claude Delaval|year=1908|work=[[Internet Archive]]|pages=339–42|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref>
Hume served in the [[Walcheren Expedition]] in 1809, and the [[Peninsula War]]. During that period he was surgeon to [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Arthur Wellesley]].<ref name="DNB"/><ref name="LC"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mocavo.co.uk/Roll-of-Commisssioned-Officers-in-the-Medical-Service-of-the-British-Army-Who-Served-on-Full-Pay-Within-the-Period-Between-the-Accession-of-George-Ii-and-the-Formation-of-the-Royal-Army-Medical-Corps-20-June-1727-to-23-June-1898-With-an-Introduction-Showing-the-Historical-Evolution-of-the-Corps/545964/208|title=Roll of Commisssioned Officers in the Medical Service of the British Army, Who Served on Full Pay Within the Period Between the Accession of George II and the Formation of the Royal Army Medical Corps, 20 June 1727 to 23 June 1898, With an Introduction Showing the Historical Evolution of the Corps, Page 208|accessdate=20 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427142838/http://www.mocavo.co.uk/Roll-of-Commisssioned-Officers-in-the-Medical-Service-of-the-British-Army-Who-Served-on-Full-Pay-Within-the-Period-Between-the-Accession-of-George-Ii-and-the-Formation-of-the-Royal-Army-Medical-Corps-20-June-1727-to-23-June-1898-With-an-Introduction-Showing-the-Historical-Evolution-of-the-Corps/545964/208#|archive-date=27 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Hume took part in the 1815 [[Waterloo campaign]], on the medical stall as a deputy inspector.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[William Siborne]]|title=The Waterloo Campaign, 1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RxQazrQnHSkC&pg=PA819|year=1848|publisher=E. Arber|page=819}}</ref> He attended the [[Duchess of Richmond's ball]] on 15 June, the eve of the [[Battle of Quatre Bras]].<ref>{{cite book|author=John Stewart|title=Byron and the Websters: The Letters and Entangled Lives of the Poet, Sir James Webster and Lady Frances Webster|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QKNMpvANLagC&pg=PA94|date=14 March 2008|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-8437-9|page=94}}</ref> On 18 June, the day of the [[Battle of Waterloo]], he amputated the legs of [[Alexander Gordon (British staff officer)|Sir Alexander Gordon]], who died,<ref>{{cite book|author=Colin Brown|title=The Scum of the Earth: What Happened to the Real British Heroes of Waterloo?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nOiUBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT101|date=15 May 2015|publisher=History Press Limited|isbn=978-0-7509-6426-5|page=101}}</ref> and of [[Henry William Paget, 2nd Earl of Uxbridge]], out of a number of operations.<ref>{{cite book|author=Paul O'Keeffe|title=Waterloo: The Aftermath|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L0PLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT70|date=9 October 2014|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4464-6633-9|page=70}}</ref> The following day he awoke the Duke with the casualty list.<ref>{{cite book|author=Philip J. Haythornthwaite|title=Wellington: The Iron Duke|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j6l2KWj-BP0C&pg=PA81|year=2007|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=978-1-57488-892-8|page=81}}</ref> He also attended the dying [[William Howe De Lancey]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Peter Stanley|title=For Fear of Pain, British Surgery, 1790–1850|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IWgdeeWytXUC&pg=PA268|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=90-420-1034-7|page=268}}</ref> [[File:Field of Battersea.jpg|thumb|left|''The Field of Battersea'', caricature by [[William Heath (artist)|William Heath]] of the 1829 duel between [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]] (as lobster) and [[George Finch-Hatton, 10th Earl of Winchilsea]]; John Robert Hume, as the Duke's friend and physician, sits and spectates.]]
==Later life== The [[University of St Andrews]] conferred on Hume the degree of M.D. on 12 January 1816, and on 22 December 1819 he was admitted a licentiate of the [[Royal College of Physicians]].<ref name="DNB"/> On his own account, he had previously been in France with the Duke of Wellington.<ref>{{cite book|author=Great Britain. Parliament. House of Commons|title=Parliamentary Papers, House of Commons and Command|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kEsSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA191|year=1834|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|page=191}}</ref> From half-pay, he was made an Inspector of Hospitals in 1820.<ref>[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/Edinburgh/issue/2809/page/164/data.pdf ''Edinburgh Gazette'' (PDF)]</ref>
Settling in London, Hume became personal physician to the Duke.<ref name="DNB"/> His patients included Marianne Patterson in 1824, shortly to marry the Duke's brother Richard.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jehanne Wake|title=Sisters of Fortune: America's Caton Sisters at Home and Abroad|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9vIQ4J28Tn8C&pg=PA187|date=28 February 2012|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4516-0763-5|page=187}}</ref> He travelled with the Duke to [[St Petersburg]] in 1826,<ref>{{cite book|author=Arthur Aspinall|title=The Letters of King George IV|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lvw8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA140|year=1938|publisher=CUP Archive|pages=140–1|id=GGKEY:9AN5KT99PTA}}</ref> and was present at the Duke's duel with the [[George Finch-Hatton, 10th Earl of Winchilsea|Earl of Winchelsea]], fought in 1829 as part of the [[Catholic Emancipation]] controversy.<ref>{{cite book|author=F. M. L. Thompson|title=University of London and the World of Learning, 1836–1986|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uHOvAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA149|date=1 July 1990|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-0-8264-3827-0|page=149}}</ref><ref>{{cite ODNB|id=9447|title=Hatton, George William Finch-|first=John|last=Wolffe}}</ref> He was made a commissioner for the licensing of Middlesex asylums in 1828.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bulletins and Other State Intelligence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BqU1AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA150|year=1828|publisher=Compiled and arranged from the official documents published in the London gazette.|page=150}}</ref>
Hume was created D.C.L. at Oxford on 13 June 1834, the Duke being then chancellor of the university. He was admitted a fellow of the College of Physicians on 9 July 1836, and on the following 1 September was appointed one of the metropolitan [[commissioners in lunacy]].<ref name="DNB"/> Following the resignation of [[William Frederick Chambers]], Hume at this period also became Examining Physician to the [[East India Company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/b21352148_0#page/n179/mode/2up|title=A History of the Indian Medical Service, 1600–1913 [electronic resource]|last=Crawford|first=Dirom Grey|year=1914|work=[[Internet Archive]]|page=164|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref> He was sufficiently well known to feature in the early writings of the [[Brontë family]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Heather Glen|title=The Cambridge Companion to the Brontës|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-U0mwaEN7e0C&pg=PA34|date=5 December 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-77971-5|page=34}}</ref>
Hume was attacked and defended in ''[[The Lancet]]'' of the later 1840s, with other commissioners of lunacy, accused of being bedridden with gout, and a "[[sinecurist]]"; though he was active in inspections.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Lancet|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pwdBAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA75|year=1849|publisher=J. Onwhyn|page=75}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Lancet|editor=Thomas Wakley|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pTVPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA294|year=1846|page=294}}</ref> He subsequently became inspector general of hospitals, and was made C.B. 16 August 1850. He died at his house in [[Curzon Street]], Mayfair, London, on 1 March 1857, aged 75.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Family== Hume married Elizabeth, daughter of David Limond, at Ayr on 1 July 1804.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Scots Magazine, and Edinburgh Literary Miscellany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NNgPAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA564|year=1804|pages=564–5}}</ref> Their daughter Elizabeth married Archibald Campbell of Glendaruel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kilmodan-colintraive.org.uk/history/glorious-glendaruel/|title=Glorious Glendaruel, The Friends of Kilmodan and Colintraive|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=January 2014}} {{Orphan|date=March 2013}} }}
'''Kathe S. Perez''' is an [[Speech-language pathology|speech pathologist]] who has focused her work on helping those in the [[transgender]] community discover their true voice through the use of her [[voice feminization]] program.
==Biography== Perez was born on August 22 in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]], [[Puerto Rico]] and spent her childhood in West Haven, Conn.<ref name="kathesperez">[http://www.kathesperez.com www.kathesperez.com], March 2012</ref> She is founder and president of Exceptional Voice, Inc. which has headquarters in [[Denver]], [[Colorado|Colo]].<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice">“Out of the Darkness: The Remarkable Story of Kathe Perez, '86,” [http://www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org], August 27, 2009</ref><ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a">“Kathe Perez, ’86,” [http://www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org]. Retrieved January 15, 2013</ref>
Of mixed heritage (Mexican-Irish-German-American) and from a family of modest means, Perez felt a bit different living in affluent [[Connecticut]]. From this early outsider experience, Perez sought to discover her own true voice.<ref name="kathesperez" /> Early on, she explored her talent as a singer, but she soon found that her skills as a special education teacher helping young children with learning and emotional difficulties find their voices best fit her, that experience lead her to pursue her graduate degree in speech pathology.<ref>{{cite web|author=In Touch with SLHS/CDSS Alumni |url=http://www.speechlanguagepractice.org/ |title=In Touch with SLHS/CDSS Alumni |publisher=Speechlanguagepractice.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-27}}</ref> During her graduate studies, she discovered her now current passion for the human voice – speech and voice therapy. Kathe has done extensive graduate and PhD work in the field, and has helped people from all corners of the globe find their true voice.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice" />
Perez currently resides with her partner Kevin.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" /> Her two adult daughters share her passion of advocacy and [[non-profit]] projects for the underserved populations.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" /> In her free time, Kathe enjoys running (she ran four half marathons in one year), snowshoeing, hiking, gardening, traveling, live theater and reading.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice" /><ref>“Race History,” [http://www.Athlinks.com www.Athlinks.com], retrieved January 17. 2013</ref>
==Career== Perez is an expert in the care and training of the human voice, and for more than 25 years she has helped thousands find their true voices. As founder and president of Exceptional Voice, Inc., she specializes in giving those in the transgender (TG) community the voice training and tools they need to live their lives to the fullest and most authentic expression of their true gender.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice" /><ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" />
A certified speech-language pathologist, Perez developed a voice feminization training system that has helped individuals from all over the world express themselves as the women they truly are.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asha.org/Members/ASHA-Makes-a-Difference/ |title=ASHA Makes a Difference |publisher=Asha.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-27}}</ref> From her [http://www.30daycrashcourse.com/ 30-Day Crash Course] [http://www.30daycrashcourse.com/ Transgender Voice Feminization Program]<ref>Olsen-Stanko, Kelly (June 6, 2010). [http://forum.beginninglifeforums.com/index.php/mv/tree/7247/ba3e1065afa5921135efcfa69870ae1d/ “A look inside voice feminization therapy for transgender patients],” Beginning Life Forums</ref> and [https://www.youtube.com/user/tgvoice YouTube channel]<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" /> to one-on-one sessions, Kathe has given thousands of TG women a variety of resources they can use to transform their voices.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" />
Perez has presented and demonstrated her voice feminization techniques and exercises at conferences around the world including, [http://www.be-all.org/ Be-All], [http://www.california-dreamin.org/ California Dreamin’], [http://www.outboulder.org/content/colorado-gold-rush Colorado Gold Rush], [http://www.espritconf.com/ Esprit], [http://www.fantasiafair.org/ Fantasia Fair], [http://www.firstevent.us/ First Event Transgender Conference], [http://www.femmecollective.com/ Holiday en Femme], [http://www.ifge.org/ IFGE Conference], [http://www.transcentralpa.org/keystone.htm Keystone Conference], and [http://www.sccatl.org/content/ Southern Comfort Conference].
She has co-authored a number of scholarly articles for professional publications. She collaborated with noted voice coach Lynn Skinner for the voice feminization audio training series "Fundamentals of Your Feminine Voice" [http://www.voicefeminization.com/,<ref>Olsen-Stanko, Kelly (June 6, 2010). [http://forum.beginninglifeforums.com/index.php/mv/tree/7247/ba3e1065afa5921135efcfa69870ae1d/ “A look inside voice feminization therapy for transgender patients]”, Beginning Life Forums</ref> which has received international recognition and acclaim.
She also provides speech, voice and public speaking training programs for companies and small businesses as well as individuals such as singers, actors, broadcasters, auctioneers and teachers.<ref>[http://naanews.wordpress.com/2012/08/03/benefit-auction-summit-to-focus-on-presentation-skills-voice-care-and-event-planning/ Benefit Auction Summit to focus on presentation skills, voice care and event planning,”] Auction Enews, August 3, 2012</ref> She has taught graduate and undergraduate courses at the University of Colorado [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]], Metropolitan State College Denver and the University of Northern Colorado Greeley.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice" /> Nationally, she has conducted customized workshops, seminars and training programs for professionals who wish to improve their voices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asha.org/Members/ASHA-Makes-a-Difference |title=ASHA Makes a Difference |publisher=Asha.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-27}}</ref>
In 1993, Perez undertook doctorate coursework for speech and voice motor learning at the [[University of Colorado]] Boulder. She received her Master of Arts degree from the [[University of Colorado]]-Boulder in 1986.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice_a" /> She studied under famed Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences Professor [http://www.lsvtglobal.com/about-us/founders/lorraine-ramig Lorraine Ramig], PhD,<ref>“Kathe Perez, ’86,” [http://www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org www.SpeechLanguagePractice.org]. Retrieved January 15, 2013.</ref> at the [[University of Colorado]]-Boulder and interned with Robert Sataloff, MD.<ref name="SpeechLanguagePractice" /> She is a certified speech-language pathologist and a member of the American Speech-Language and Hearing Association.<ref>[https://books.google.com-books-about-Professional voice.html?id=bvNsAAAAMAAJ Professional Voice: The Science and Art of Clinical Care] (2005) by Robert Sataloff</ref>
==Publications== Perez has written for a number of professional publications, including chapters on clinical voice therapy and clinical voice laboratory in the much-acclaimed textbook, Professional Voice: The Science and Art of Clinical Care (2005) by Robert Sataloff.<ref>[https://books.google.com-books-about-Professional voice.html?id=bvNsAAAAMAAJ Vocal Health and Pedagogy] (2006), also by Sataloff</ref> In addition, she has contributed to ''Vocal Health and Pedagogy'' (2006), also by Sataloff.<ref>[https://books.google.com-books-about-Professional voice.html?id=bvNsAAAAMAAJ Vocal Health and Pedagogy (2006)], also by Sataloff</ref> Her research appears in a number of scholarly papers that have been published in professional journals.

volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://keepachildalive.org/}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Keep a Child Alive''' (KCA) is a [[nonprofit organization]] that provides healthcare, housing, and other support services to [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]]-affected communities in Africa and India.{{cite web|url=https://nonprofitquarterly.org/2012/07/12/alicia-keys-nonprofit-honors-oprah-winfrey/|title=Alicia Keys’ Nonprofit Honors Oprah Winfrey|work=[[Nonprofit Quarterly]]|date=July 12, 2012|accessdate=March 22, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nonprofitpro.com/article/keep-child-alive-raises-over-130-000-during-bet-awards-show-through-mgive-mobile-donation-program-409207/all/|title=Keep a Child Alive Raises Over $130,000 During BET Awards Show Through mGive- Mobile Donation Program|work=NonProfitPRO|date=July 1, 2009|accessdate=March 22, 2018}} Co-founded by Leigh Blake and [[Alicia Keys]], the organization aims to "realize the end of AIDS for children and families, by combating the physical, social and economic impacts of HIV."{{cite web|url=http://keepachildalive.org/about-us/|title=About Us|publisher=Keep a Child Alive|accessdate=March 22, 2018}} Keep a Child Alive organizes the annual [[The Black Ball|Black Ball]], a fundraiser gala, established in 2004, where celebrities and philanthropists gather to support and raise awareness for the cause. Since the first Black Ball, the organization has raised over $28.7 million for HIV/AIDS treatment.{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7518977/chance-the-rapper-salt-n-pepa-alicia-keys-keep-a-child-alive-black-ball|title=Chance The Rapper & Salt-N-Pepa to Join Alicia Keys as Performers at Keep A Child Alive's Black Ball|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=September 26, 2016|accessdate=March 25, 2018}} ==Background== KCA cofounder and President Leigh Blake was first inspired to start this initiative in 2003 after an encounter at the AIDS Research and Family Care Clinic, a place which she helped fund, in [[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]]. A woman named Anne brought her 3-year-old son Brine for medical care, refusing to leave until she received the “drugs that you have in [[United States|America]] for your children.” [http://www.keepachildalive.org/ Keep a Child Alive- About] Blake, who had already become involved in the AIDS [[epidemic]] using her background in the music and film industry to co-found the [http://www.redhot.com Red Hot Organization] and Artists Against AIDS Worldwide, told Anne that she would pay for the drugs. In so doing, the idea for Keep a Child Alive was born. The drugs were about $12000 a year through the [[New York University]] Hospital AIDS Research Department, which at that time was overseeing care at the clinic through Dr. Shaffiq Essajee. It was not long before word started to spread and friends of Blake and Essajee offered to make contributions. The first donor was Peter Edge and soon, KCA co-founder and Global Ambassador [[Alicia Keys]] joined the cause, sponsoring children along with [[Iman (model)|Iman]] and many others. In 2003, Keep a Child Alive was officially founded. The clinic in Kenya that led to Blake's vision became a model for other facilities that KCA now aspires to build throughout Africa and the developing world.[http://www.keepachildalive.org/ Keep a Child Alive- About] KCA cofounder Alicia Keys was first affected by the HIV/AIDs crisis at 8 years old when her mother's friend died from the disease. She discovered first-hand the extensive impact of the AIDS epidemic years later when she visited [[South Africa]], a trip that was the impetus to cofounding Keep a Child Alive. Keys had befriended AIDS activist Leigh Blake, who had reached out to her and helped raise her awareness to the global impact of HIV/AIDS. Keys and Leigh visited South African clinics with HIV-infected mothers and children, where Keys encountered the lack of resources and education on the disease present in the communities.{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/celebrity/alicia-keys-opens-up-about-fighting-hivaids-black-ball-fundraiser/|title=Alicia Keys Opens Up About Fighting HIV/AIDS, Black Ball Fundraiser|date=October 30, 2015|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|access-date=March 25, 2018}} Keys visited other African countries such as [[Uganda]] and Kenya to promote care for children affected by AIDS.{{cite web|date=April 10, 2006|title=For The Record: Quick News On Gwyneth Paltrow, Chris Martin, Obie Trice, Notorious B.I.G., Jessica Simpson & More|work=MTV News|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1528266/20060410/coldplay.jhtml|accessdate=December 16, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227235047/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1528266/20060410/coldplay.jhtml| archivedate= December 27, 2008 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|date=April 16, 2006|title=Alicia Keys and 'Keep a Child Alive' Visit AHF's Ithembalabantu Clinic, Free AIDS Clinic in Durban, South Africa Run by AIDS Healthcare Foundation|agency=PR Newswire|url=http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=168584|accessdate=December 4, 2006}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-04-06-alicia-keys_x.htm|title=Alicia Keys in Kenya for HIV Project|date=April 6, 2006|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|accessdate=July 17, 2009}} Her work in Africa was documented in the documentary ''Alicia in Africa: Journey to the Motherland''.{{cite news|date=April 7, 2008|title=Alicia Keys' Documentary "Alicia in Africa: Journey to the Motherland" Available...|agency=Reuters|publisher=Thomson Reuters|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/spiralfrog/child_alive/prweb838624.htm|accessdate=November 2, 2010}} ==The Mission== Keep a Child Alive brings attention to the already 30 million people that have been killed by AIDS in [[sub-Saharan Africa]] and the millions more that are threatened and orphaned by the disease. Currently there are 33.3 million people living with HIV/AIDS, including 2.3 million children under the age of 15. Despite AIDS being a preventable and treatable disease, 2.9 million people died from AIDS related causes last year, including 380,000 children under the age of 15—the equivalent of one child dying per minute.[http://keepachildalive.org/images/handbook.pdf] KCA's efforts continue to focus in particular on sub-Saharan Africa as it remains the worst-affected region in the world. With a little more than one-tenth of the world's population living in this area, it is home to almost 64 percent of all people living with HIV—of the overall 24.5 million infected, 2 million are children. While access to ARV therapy has increased more than eightfold since the end of 2003, only 30 percent of people in need of treatment receive it. In addition to improving access to ARV therapy, KCA offers a range of support services including nutritional projects, diagnostic testing, training of health care workers, counseling, and funding sites where AIDS orphans can be cared for. There are currently 14.9 million AIDS orphans in Africa alone, 16.6 worldwide. ==Sites== Keep a Child Alive currently provides funding to 10 clinical and orphan care sites in 5 countries: India, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda and South Africa with past funding to additional projects in Ethiopia, Mali, India, Kenya, South Africa and Zimbabwe. With KCA funding, these projects have been successfully scaled to new levels of service and self-sustainability within their communities. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Country ! Location ! Nairobi |- | India | Chandrakal Orphanage | Hyderabad |- | Mali | The Hope Center Clinic Initiative | Sikoro |- | Zimbabwe | Mashambanzou Care Trust | Harare |} ==Campaigns== '''''Spirit of a Child'''''
The [http://www.keepachildalive.org/postdards.pdf Spirit of a Child] campaign was one of KCA's first major endeavors to engage the public through "groundbreaking advertising and media campaigns" that "reinvent the way the public perceives their role in the issue."[http://www.keepachildalive.org/ Keep a Child Alive- About] The campaign, which was created for KCA by [https://www.tbwachiat.com/ TBWA/Chiat Day] and photographed by Marc Baptiste, was launched on November 3, 2005 at the annual [[The Black Ball|Black Ball]] fundraiser. "Spirit of a Child" is the brainchild of Patrick O'Neill and Nikki Weinstein and features the children of Agape Orphanage paired with such celebrities as [[Kanye West]], [[David Byrne]], [[Lorraine Bracco]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[Cynthia Nixon]], [[Nas]], [[John Legend]] and others. '''''I Am African'''''
The ''I Am African'' campaign stirred up controversy with its appropriation of tribal markings and face-paint worn by noted celebrities like [[Gisele Bündchen]], [[Gwyneth Paltrow]], [[David Bowie]], [[Sarah Jessica Parker]], and [[Sting (musician)|Sting]]. The concept was created in the summer of 2006 by model and cosmetics entrepreneur [[Iman (model)|Iman]] to reflect the idea that Africa is the mother continent of all human beings.[[Givhan, Robin]]. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/02/AR2006110201710_pf.html Dressing Up in the Latest Fashionable Cause?] ''Washington Post''. 3 November 2006: C2 Photographed by Michael Thompson, the ads initially appeared in a fashion supplement to [[Condé Nast]] magazines in September and has since received both positive and negative attention in the press, blogs, and among other social activists.James, Caryn. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/13/arts/13halo.html?ex=1321074000&en=0587bdf1f4d28ba2&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss Megastars Out to Save the World: Those Halos can Tarnish in an Instant]. ''New York Times''. 13 November 2006: E3 '''''Become A Drug Dealer'''''
[http://www.becomeadrugdealer.com Become A Drug Dealer] is another KCA campaign that gives people the opportunity to purchase the drugs necessary to keep a child alive either by buying a T-shirt with the words ''Drug Dealer'' printed on it or making the typical monthly donation. '''''Buy Life'''''
The Buy Life campaign seeks to change consumer behavior, to reposition consumerism and the act of buying in the nonprofit environment through social media. With the tagline "The More You Buy, The More You Save," created by [https://www.tbwachiat.com/ TBWA/Chiat Day], and photographed by [[Markus Klinko]] and [[Indrani]], this series of portraits of notable celebrities in T-shirts with personalized scanable [[barcodes]], turns the commercialism of celebrity packaging into a literal bar code that consumers can scan to buy life for the ultimate instant gratification. The campaign features celebrities including [[Katie Holmes]], [[Kim Kardashian]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]], [[Ryan Seacrest]], [[Alicia Keys]], [[Jaden Smith|Jaden]] and [[Willow Smith]], [[Swizz Beatz]], [[Serena Williams]], and styling by [[GK Reid]]. KCA is the first charity to use barcode technology on [[smartphone]] devices to engage the public and encourage the purchase of life.Wallace, Amy. "Farewell, Digital World." [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/28/business/28proto.html?src=busln] ''New York Times''http://blog.keepachildalive.org/post/1256031907/buy-life-the-more-you-buy-the-more-you-save '''''Digital Death'''''
The Digital Death campaign launched December 1, 2010 for [[World AIDS Day]] with shocking images of celebrities posed in coffins, photographed by Markus Klinko & [[Indrani (photographer)|Indrani]], with taglines "[[Kim Kardashian]] is Dead", "Ryan Seacrest is Dead", etc. created by TBWA/Chiat Day. The image art is accompanied by performance art/interactive dimensions, with the stars sacrificing their digital lives on [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] until their fans donate one million dollars to buy their lives back. Among the other celebrities featured in the campaign were [[Alicia Keys]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Justin Timberlake]], [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] and [[Serena Williams]]. [[Daphne Guinness]] explains, "This campaign is so striking and draws attention not only to the AIDS disaster in Africa but also to how we have lost our way in what we care about."Davis, Dawn "Kim Kardashian, Daphne Guinness and More Go Twitter-Silent for a Cause" November 30, 2010 http://www.harpersbazaar.com/bazaar-blog/kim-kardashian-keep-a-child-alive-113010 The million dollar donation goal was reached in six days.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} ==Corporate Partners== KCA maintains that the reason it is able to give such a large percentage of monthly donations is because it relies on larger contributions from foundations, corporations, and major individual donors to support management and administrative costs.[http://www.keepachildalive.org/ Keep a Child Alive- About] The [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], [[Donna Karan]], [[Time Warner Cable]], and [[Maybelline]] are just a few of KCA's many corporate partners. The full list can be accessed here. [http://www.keepachildalive.org/about_corporate.php] ==Mobile Fundraising== In Fall 2008, Keep a Child Alive launched a [[mobile donating]] campaign with Co-Founder and Global Ambassador [[Alicia Keys]]. Keys raised over $40,000 in [[micro-donations]] by asking concert goers to text ALIVE to 90999.[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS188626+02-Jul-2008+PRN20080702 Keep a Child Alive and Alicia Keys Raise $40,000 Through Mobile Donations During Fall 2008 Concert Tour]. July 2008. The mobile giving campaign was created through a partnership between Keep a Child Alive, the [[Mobile Giving Foundation]] and [[Mgive]].[http://nonprofit.about.com/od/socialmedia/a/mobilegiving.htm Mobile Giving- How to Make it Work for Your Nonprofit]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.keepachildalive.org Keep a Child Alive] - Official site * [http://www.keepachildalivestore.org/ KCA Store] - Store sells T-shirts, music, wrist bands, etc. {{Alicia Keys}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Keep A Child Alive}} [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in New York (state)]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS in Africa]]

revision.comment: /* Early history and Hannah Riddell */ expansion
revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=December 2009}} {{Nihongo|'''Keisai Aoki'''|青木恵哉|Aoki Keisai|extra=April 8, 1893 – March 6, 1969}} was a Japanese [[missionary]] who paved the way to the establishment of Hansen's disease sanatorium Kunigami-Airakuen, Okinawa, now [[Okinawa Airakuen Sanatorium]], [[Japan]]. At the age of 16 he developed leprosy and later, under the guidance of [[Hannah Riddell]], he also helped people with leprosy in Okinawa.
{{Infobox person |name = Keisai Aoki |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = April 8, 1893 |birth_place = [[Tokushima Prefecture]], [[Japan]] |death_date = {{d-da|March 6, 1969|April 8, 1893}} |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = Helping Okinawan leprosy patients, leading to the establishment of leper hospital [[Okinawa Airakuen Sanatorium]] |occupation = Missionary |nationality = Japan }}
== Early history and Hannah Riddell == Keisai Aoki (real name Yasujiro Aoki) was born in [[Tokushima]] Prefecture on April 8, 1893. At the age of 16 he developed leprosy and everything did not help, including the pilgrimage of 88 holy places of [[Shikoku]] (at that time it was believed to be of help). In 1916 he entered the Oshima Leprosarium and was baptized in 1918 as a Christian. He helped with missionary work, and he sent a letter to [[Hannah Riddell]] since he was worried about women's temptation. At [[Kusatsu, Gunma|Kusatsu]], he met Riddell who was vacationing there and decided to go to Kaishun Hospital, where she was the director. He helped with her missionary work in the facility, which he described as having an almost monastic atmosphere.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Hannah Riddell: An Englishwoman in Japan|last=Boyd|first=Julia|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Company, Inc.|year=2012|isbn=9781462903818|location=Rutland, VT|pages=}}</ref>
During his time at the hospital, he met Aiko Tamaki, who he became attracted to. This, however, worried him because this was against Riddell's strict policy of gender segregation. He decided to go to Okinawa to pursue missionary work at the strong suggestion of Riddell.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} It is not clear whether Riddell discovered Keisai's affection for Tamaki or whether he was asked to leave because of it. However, Keisai, himself, described Riddell's devotion to her patients even those who left under difficult circumstances, sending them letters and gifts after their departure.<ref name=":0" />
== Okinawa and Okinawa Airakuen Sanatorium == With missionary Arato, he discovered people with leprosy living in caves or other places, first on Iejima Island, and later on Mainland [[Okinawa]], and they gave them clothes, food and spiritual ministry. At one place, village people burned down the houses of people with leprosy. They also discovered about 40 people forced to live in a small island called Jalma Island. Later they landed at Yagaji Island (some sources say Gayachi Island<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://leprosyhistory.org/database/person334|title=Keisai Aoki {{!}} International Leprosy Association - History of Leprosy|website=leprosyhistory.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>), where they acquired a piece of land, which Keisai eventually used to found the Kunigami (later Okingawa) Airakuen Sanatorium [[Okinawa Airakuen Sanatorium]] in 1938. In 1957, he became an official missionary of [[Okinawa]] Seikokai (Episcopal Church). On March 6, 1969, he died of myocardial infarction.
==Haiku== Keisai also composed many short poems ([[haiku]]). These include the following: :Koetekite, Hone o Uzumuru, Hito Ha kana ::Coming over to Okinawa, I am like a leaf, my bones will be buried here.
==Leprosy in Okinawa before Aoki== Among the Japanese prefectures, leprosy had the highest incidence in Okinawa Prefecture in 1925, 1935 and 1940. The Okinawa Government was inconsistent concerning the establishment of leprosaria. In 1931, Miyako Hoyoen Sanatorium was established on Miyako Island, but it was met with strong opposition from the mainland Okinawans. Rioting and burning of houses of leprosy patients occurred. With the help of various organizations and individuals such as [[Kensuke Mitsuda]] and Fumio Hayashi, the Kunigami Airakuen, now the [[Okinawa Airakuen Sanatorium]], was established due to the efforts and leadership of Keisai Aoki.<ref>Leprosy Control Measures Kazuo Saikawa, Okinawa Leprosy Prevention Association, 1999.</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.tenro.net/libell/t-aoki.htm Photograph] *Barato Sumire No.27, (2009). In Japanese *Aoki Keisai Dozo Jomaku Kinen (Statue Unveiling Ceremony)(2005) Okinawa Airakun Jichikai. In Japanese *Hansen's disease policy(1999) Kazuo Saikawa Okinawaken Hansenbyo Yobo Kyokai. In Japanese *Erabareta Shima(1972) Keisai Aoki, Shinkyo Shuppan Sha, Tokyo. in Japanese *Aoki Keisai, ''Mission to Okinawa'', Christian Book Room, Hong Kong, (a 352-page English translation of autobiography). *[http://shimingakkai.com/syuukyou/5.html 青木恵哉とその時代] *[http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110004814084 On the "Chosen island", abstract in English]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aoki Keisai}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Leprosy activists]] [[Category:Japanese Protestant missionaries]] [[Category:Leprosy in Japan]] [[Category:Protestant missionaries in Japan]] [[Category:Leprosy nurses and caregivers]]

revision.text:
'''Kenneth L. Curtis''' (born August 3, 1965) is a former college student from [[Connecticut]] who on October 30, 1987 shot and killed his estranged girlfriend, and shot himself in the head. He was charged criminally for the killing, but originally was found [[competence (law)|mentally incompetent to stand trial]], and had the criminal charges dismissed.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/17/nyregion/guilty-plea-in-87-killing-case-altered-competency-laws.html?pagewanted=1|accessdate=March 10, 2010|work=New York Times | title=Guilty Plea in '87 Killing; Case Altered Competency Laws | first=Neil | last=MacFarquhar | date=September 17, 1999}}</ref> Years later, he enrolled in college, and pursued studies as a [[pre-med]] student. He again was charged with the killing, found competent, and subsequently pleaded guilty to manslaughter.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/26/nyregion/metro-news-briefs-connecticut-student-loses-his-bid-to-quash-murder-counts.html | work=The New York Times | title=METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT; Student Loses His Bid To Quash Murder Counts | date=August 26, 1998 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}}</ref>
The case (''Connecticut vs. Kenneth Curtis'') changed the views in the justice system of mental competence to stand trial.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Social Work and the Law: Proceedings of the National Organization of Forensic Social Work, 2000|author1=Neighbors, I.|author2=National Organization of Forensic Social Work|date=2002|publisher=Haworth Press|isbn=9780789015488|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5s7QSTvIi70C&pg=PA15|page=15|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> Prior to this case, those given such an assessment were viewed as not restorable, and charges would be dismissed in favor of periodic reviews used only in determining the need for a [[civil commitment]].<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=Social Work and the Law: Proceedings of the National Organization of Forensic Social Work, 2000|author1=Neighbors, I.|author2=National Organization of Forensic Social Work|date=2002|publisher=Haworth Press|isbn=9780789015488|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5s7QSTvIi70C&pg=PA16|page=16|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref>
==The case== On October 30, 1987, Curtis shot his estranged girlfriend Donna Kalson in a bar parking lot in [[Stratford, Connecticut]], killing her. He then shot himself in a [[murder-suicide]] attempt. He also injured one of Kalson's friends who was in her company in the process. After a lengthy hospitalization in which he was on [[advanced life support]], he survived his own shot, leaving him severely disabled.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/US/9712/26/legal.quandary/ | work=CNN | title=Connecticut in legal quandary over man accused of murder | accessdate=May 7, 2010}}</ref> He was partially [[brain damage]]d and [[paralysis|paralyzed]].
After being released from the hospital, Curtis was charged with Kalson's murder and the attempted murder of her friend.<ref name="people">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20124442,00.html|publisher=people.com|title=Fit to Be Tried|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> But following his recovery, more than a year after the incident, he was given a [[Competency evaluation (law)|mental competence evaluation]] to determine if he could stand trial for his crimes. During the evaluation, it was found that his ability to read or understand were impaired, and he had no memory of the incident. As a result, he was ruled mentally incompetent to stand trial. But he was not ordered to be confined to a [[mental institution]]. He was allowed to return home. Kalson's family was initially unaware of this.
This did not sit well with Donna Kalson's parents when they learned, following a tip, that Curtis was attending a local college. The Kalsons arranged for their own investigation of Curtis. Reporters for [[WTNH|News Channel 8]] observed Curtis taking classes at a local college with an apparent goal of a career in [[psychiatry]]. His grades were mostly As and Bs; his [[grade point average]] after receiving 48 [[college credit|credits]] was 3.3,<ref name="miaminewtimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/1997-12-11/news/news-of-the-weird/|publisher=miaminewtimes.com|title=News of the Weird | Miami New Times|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> information that was obtained from a [[search warrant]] on Curtis's grades at three colleges executed by [[Stratford, Connecticut|Stratford]] police.<ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=Social Work and the Law: Proceedings of the National Organization of Forensic Social Work, 2000|author1=Neighbors, I.|author2=National Organization of Forensic Social Work|date=2002|publisher=Haworth Press|isbn=9780789015488|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5s7QSTvIi70C&pg=PA16|page=16|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> His actions on campus, including a conversation the reporters had directly with Curtis, were filmed by reporters. While Curtis's defense team called many doctors to testify on his behalf, the video produced by the network was viewed as overwhelming evidence in favor of declaring him mentally competent.<ref name="wtnh">{{cite web|url=http://video.wtnh.com/news/1999/may/05131999-curtis.html|publisher=video.wtnh.com|title=news/1999/may/05131999-curtis|accessdate=February 17, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718122239/http://video.wtnh.com/news/1999/may/05131999-curtis.html|archivedate=July 18, 2011|df=}}</ref>
Curtis's defense team attempted to fight the actions taken against him, claiming that he was already declared incompetent and could not be tried due to a Connecticut law that required such closure of all cases of this type after 18 months. They took their battles all the way to the [[Connecticut Supreme Court]].<ref name="wtnh2">{{cite web|url=http://video.wtnh.com/news/1998/sep/093098.html|publisher=video.wtnh.com|title=news/1998/sep/093098|accessdate=February 17, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718122428/http://video.wtnh.com/news/1998/sep/093098.html|archivedate=July 18, 2011|df=}}</ref> But [[double jeopardy]] laws and other laws were not considered to be applicable, and Curtis was ordered to stand trial.
Curtis [[guilty plea|pleaded guilty]] in 1999 to [[manslaughter]] and received a 20-year prison sentence, the maximum allowed for charges of manslaughter.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/dec/04/news/mn-40924 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Man Found Incompetent but Gets Prison | date=December 4, 1999 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}}</ref><ref name="state">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctinmateinfo.state.ct.us/detailsupv.asp?id_inmt_num=260245|publisher=ctinmateinfo.state.ct.us|title=www.ctinmateinfo.state.ct.us/detailsupv.asp?id_inmt_num=260245|accessdate=February 17, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723141146/http://www.ctinmateinfo.state.ct.us/detailsupv.asp?id_inmt_num=260245|archivedate=July 23, 2011|df=}}</ref>
Curtis was paroled in 2011.<ref name="wtnh3">{{cite web|url=http://www.wtnh.com/dpp/news/crime/convicted-murderer-out-on-parole#.UQBqumt5mSM|publisher=wtnh.com|title=Connecticut Local News and News 8 Video - New Haven, Hartford | WTNH|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20124442,00.html People Magazine article on the Kenneth Curtis case; describes many details] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=5s7QSTvIi70C&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15&dq=%22kenneth+curtis%22murder&as_brr=3&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html Social Work and the Law] by Ira A. Neighbors, Anne Chambers, Ellen Levin, Gila Nordman, Cynthia Tutrone, National Organization of Forensic Social Work, {{ISBN|0-7890-1548-X}}, pages 15-19; describes the case and its impact on the justice system
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Curtis, Kenneth}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people convicted of manslaughter]] [[Category:Mental health law in the United States]] [[Category:1965 births]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} The [[eight-thousander]]s are the 14 [[mountain]]s that rise more than {{convert|8000|m|ft|0}} above [[sea level]]; they are all in the [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] and [[Karakoram]] [[mountain range]]s.
This is a list of [[Mountaineering|mountaineers]] who have died on these mountains. [[File:Flight over himalaya annotated.jpg|thumb|750px|Six of the fourteen summits of the eight-thousanders (Manaslu, Shishapangma, Cho Oyu, Lhotse, Mt. Everest and Makalu).]] == Mount Everest == [[File:Mount Everest North Face.jpg|thumb|North face of Mount Everest.]] {{main article|List of people who died climbing Mount Everest}} [[Mount Everest]], [[Earth]]'s highest mountain, has been host to numerous tragedies; over 297 have died on the mountain, with deaths occurring every year since 1978. The most notable events occurred during the [[1922 British Mount Everest Expedition]], [[1970 Everest Disaster]], [[1974 Everest Disaster]], [[1996 Everest Disaster]], [[2014 Mount Everest avalanche]], and [[2015 Mount Everest avalanches]]. See the complete [[list of people who died climbing Mount Everest]].
== K2 == [[K2]] is the world's second highest mountain.
[[File:K2 from North.jpg|thumb|Northern vantage of K2.]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=July 2014}} {{orphan|date=May 2014}} }}
'''Ma3looma''' is an Egyptian website aimed to raise awareness about [[sexual and reproductive health]] (SRH) issues among the Egyptian youth. The website addresses the current problem that Egyptian youth/students are insufficiently educated about SRH issues due to their relatives/teachers being embarrassed or unprepared to discuss this issue due to social taboos.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2012/egypt-adolescents-schools-sexual-education.aspx | work= PRB | title= Quality Sexual Education Needed for Adolescents in Egyptian Schools }}</ref> Ma3looma uses various social media platforms as well as its own website to expose at-risk populations and the Egyptian youth coming to age in a digital era “… to anonymous, accurate, and non-judgmental information about their health and rights using OneWorld’s mobile phone and web-based question-and-answer service, which is managed and staffed by trained counselors from the Egyptian Family Health Service (EFHS).” <ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref> Ma3looma is operating via Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.
Ma3looma is funded by the [[Ford Foundation]] and is a project within One World's Mobile4Good portfolio.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref>
== Historical context == There is a danger of inattention to [[HIV/AIDS]] that lurks within the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, specifically Egypt, that could lead to a repeat of situations seen in “Indonesia, Africa or China where initial disregard or delayed reaction has ended in large number of orphans, a shortage of workers and huge health expenditures to care for HIV/AIDS patients.” <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.merip.org/mer/mer233/hivaids-middle-east-north-africa | work= MEIRP | title= HIV/AIDS in the Middle East and North Africa }}</ref> Young people worldwide are considered an ‘at-risk’ population due to participation in risky behaviors such as taking drugs, experimenting sexually, and failing to use condoms. Sexual education is a necessity among youth worldwide and Egyptian youth is no exception.
In Egypt, adolescent SRH education is controversial and is opposed by some parents, religious and community leaders, policymakers, service providers, and young people due to social taboos and the belief that these issues are too embarrassing to discuss in public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2012/egypt-adolescents-schools-sexual-education.aspx | work= PRB | title= Quality Sexual Education Needed for Adolescents in Egyptian Schools }}</ref> The lack of continuity within the society leads to school-based or home-based SRH education to be insufficient in either the amount of information and/or the accuracy of that information.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2012/egypt-adolescents-schools-sexual-education.aspx | work= PRB | title= Quality Sexual Education Needed for Adolescents in Egyptian Schools }}</ref> This obviously creates a challenge for young Egyptians, ages 10–29 which compose 40 percent of the Egyptian population, to attain important and accurate SRH information to stay healthy and safe.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref>
Enter Ma3looma which means "a piece of information," in Arabic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref> This website uses various social media platforms as well as its own website to expose at-risk populations and the Egyptian youth coming to age in a digital era “… to anonymous, accurate, and non-judgmental information about their health and rights using OneWorld’s mobile phone and web-based question-and-answer service, which is managed and staffed by trained counselors from the Egyptian Family Health Service (EFHS).”<ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref>
== Supported ==
Support from the website comes from "a collaborative network of actors, including OneWorld UK, the Egypt-based Centre for Development Services (CDS), which is responsible for the financial management of the project, the Egyptian Family Health Society (EFHS), which manages the mobile phone messaging service, as well as the UNFPA's Youth Peer Network (Y-PEER), Friends of Life (FoL), the Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR), and Qabila TV." <ref>{{cite news|url=http://oneworld.org/2013/09/19/ma3looma/ | work= oneWorld | title= Ma3looma Egypt }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.facebook.com/ma3looma.net Official Ma3looma Facebook Page] * [https://twitter.com/ma3loomaegypt Ma3looma on Twitter] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/Ma3looma Ma3looma YouTube Channel]
[[Category:Public health education]] [[Category:Health in Egypt]]
